Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 06:33:30

While working on the JSON Schema PR (remove protobuf) I've spent quite a bit of time fighting with the search functionality in @cucumber/react

I have several failing tests that I find it hard to make pass. The search code is pretty complicated, and I am struggling to maintain it.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 06:38:17

It runs a search engine (elasticlunr) in the browser. It builds a search index from the AST of all the Gherkin docs.

When a hit is found in the search index, we find the associated ASTs where a hit was found. Then we filter down the AST, removing the nodes that were not part of the hit. Then we render the filtered ASTs.

This allows users to see search results as Gherkin with everything else stripped away.

It's nice, but the code is very complicated IMO and possibly buggy. It also adds to the weight of the @cucumber/react codebase.

How bad would it be if we removed it?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:17:31

@Vincent Pretre WDYT? I know you and I spent a lot of time working on it..........

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:18:53

well, I don’t know much this is useful to end-users

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:19:20

but I recall people where eager to have the possibility to keep only failing results

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:19:37

and this filtering system uses the same code than the search (more or less)

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:19:50

It's enabled in static HTML reports, but not in online Cucumber Reports. IMO it should be the other way around.

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:19:52

so I think that if we remove that, people are going to complain

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:20:35

I think filtering should be in both products in fact

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:21:49

I wonder if there is a way to do it that doesn't require building a smaller AST from a bigger AST. That code seems fragile to me.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:23:04

A different approach would be to pass the full AST to the React component, but with an additional function prop that the react component can use to decide whether it should render a particular node or not.

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:24:31

what we would need is a way to tell upper component if content has to be displayed or not, but that’s not really how React works 😕

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:29:46

I think part of why this is hard to maintain is that we lack "strictNullChecks": true in tsconfig...

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-15 07:30:43

Enabling that creates 500 errors - ugh

Vincent Pretre
2021-03-15 07:37:47

weird, normally the code should eventually set empty lists (like the scenario for example) but not null objects 😕

David Goss
2021-03-15 10:13:24

Okay so you're thinking you (optionally) pass a filter function down as a prop? I think that could work.

David Goss
2021-03-15 10:14:19

TBH I've always found the search more powerful than I would expect, in terms of finding text anywhere in the gherkin document. I would still have been pretty impressed/happy with the search showing a list of pickle names inline and being able to click to navigate to one of them...

David Goss
2021-03-15 10:15:06

Kinda related https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/1302 (haven't gotten to a full review on that yet)

hWorblehat (https://github.com/hWorblehat)
#1302 Allow searching in HTML report via URL search param
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>The <code>react</code> library and <code>html-formatter</code> template have been updated to allow searching of the results via a URL search param.</p> <p>E.g.:</p> <pre><code>&lt;http://my.test.results/cucumber-report.html?search=%40slow&gt; </code></pre> <p>will cause the page to open with <code>@slow</code> in the search bar, and the results filtered accordingly.</p> <p>Conversely, there's a link at the bottom of the search bar that stays up-to-date with a URL of the current page with the current search and status filters.</p> <p>Here's a short demo:</p> <p>output.mp4 <strong>Details</strong></p> <p>In the <code>react</code> library, the <code>SearchQueryContext</code> has been expanded to include both the search text and the status filters. On the back of <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/1299">#1299</a>, the <code>SearchBar</code> interacts with the rest of the app entirely via this context. The <code>SearchBar</code> also has an additional optional property: a "render URL" function that is expected take a <code>SearchQuery</code> context and convert it to a URL string. If this property exists, the <code>SearchBar</code> will use it to render a link at the bottom.</p> <p>The <code>html-formatter</code> app has been changed to pass such a render function in, along with initial query search text and status filter props derived from the current URL. To do this, it makes use of a new function exported from <code>SearchQueryContext</code> that defines a default URL parser and renderer.</p> <p>All additional functionality in the <code>react</code> library is entirely optional - it must be activated by passing search text, filters, and render function in as props. Any existing app using these components should continue to behave as they did before without modifications.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>This makes it possible to create hyperlinks to a web page of cucumber<br /> results with a particular search applied. This could be used in DevOps<br /> workflows, for example by attaching a link to an issue ticket that<br /> points to a set of features tagged with the issue number.</p> <p>This is what I am trying to achieve.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>Added mocha tests for the expanded functionality in <code>SearchQueryContext</code>, <code>SearchBar</code>, and <code>QueriesWrapper</code>.</p> <p>Also tested manually with <code>html-formatter</code>.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ The change has been ported to JavaScript. ☑︎ I've added tests for my code. ☑︎ I have updated the CHANGELOG accordingly.</p>
Assignees
hWorblehat
Labels
⚡ enhancement, language: javascript, library: cucumber-react, library: html-formatter
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-03-16 16:34:53

@Aslak Hellesøy can you see a way we could extract out the search behaviour as a separate component / package and then fix it later?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-17 00:24:51

@matt-SmartBear yes definitely. shouldn’t be too hard

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-23 01:58:34

Hi @Aurélien Reeves - I'm around if you want to pair. Here is something to look at: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/1437

christian-bromann (https://github.com/christian-bromann)
#1437 [gherkin] `@cucumber/messages` release yesterday broke `@cucumber/gherkin` package
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>If you install <code>@cucumber/gherkin</code> via:</p> <pre><code>$ npm install @cucumber/gherkin </code></pre> <p>You download <code>@cucumber/gherkin@17.0.2</code> which has a file <code>node_modules/@cucumber/gherkin/dist/src/stream/GherkinStreams.js</code> that imports:</p> <pre><code>var stream_2 = require("@cucumber/messages/dist/src/stream"); </code></pre> <p>which doesn't exist anymore after the <code>@cucumber/messages</code> release yesterday. I am also a bit confused as to where this code comes from. I looked into:</p> <p>• <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-javascript">https://github.com/cucumber/gherkin-javascript</a> • <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin/javascript">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin/javascript</a> • and ultimately found the file here: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin-streams/javascript/src/GherkinStreams.ts">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin-streams/javascript/src/GherkinStreams.ts</a></p> <p>which is confusing as it now is part of the <code>@cucumber/gherkin-streams</code> package. In the <a href="https://github.com/webdriverio/webdriverio/blob/main/packages/wdio-cucumber-framework/src/index.ts#L9">webdriverio integration</a> we made use of the <code>GherkinStreams</code> class so I am wondering if <code>@cucumber/gherkin</code> got deprecated at some point.</p> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p><code>@cucumber/gherkin</code> should use an updated version of <code>@cucumber/messages</code>.</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <p>An error is being thrown:</p> <pre><code>Error: Cannot find module '@cucumber/messages/dist/src/stream Require stack - /path/to/packages/wdio-cucumber-framework/node_modules/@cucumber/gherkin/dist/src/stream/GherkinStreams.js - /path/to/packages/wdio-cucumber-framework/build/index.js </code></pre> <p><strong>Possible Solution</strong></p> <p>Update use of <code>@cucumber/messages</code> in <code>@cucumber/gherkin</code> but I have no idea if the code is still up to date and which repo I should look at.</p> <p><strong>Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)</strong></p> <ol><li><code>$ npm install @cucumber/gherkin</code></li><li>create a file that imports a class from the package, e.g. <code>import GherkinStreams from '@cucumber/gherkin/dist/src/stream/GherkinStreams'</code></li><li>run the file: <code>$ node file.js</code></li> </ol> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p><a href="https://github.com/webdriverio/webdriverio/issues/6616">webdriverio/webdriverio#6616</a></p> <p><strong>Your Environment</strong></p> <p>• Version used: • Operating System and version: • Link to your project:</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
👍 Aurélien Reeves
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-03-26 04:44:08

The old cucumber module is still 10x more popular than the new @cucumber/cucumber module:

https://snyk.io/advisor/npm-package/cucumber https://snyk.io/advisor/npm-package/@cucumber/cucumber

What can we do to increase adoption to the new?

David Goss
2021-03-26 15:46:19

*Thread Reply:* Probably two problems

• Awareness - publish a new 6.x.x patch with a big banner each time you run (not unlike the reports banner) saying "hey cucumber 7 is out over here and has these features!" • Hesitancy - ask the community why they might be avoiding upgrading even if they know about the new version. My sense from seeing some slack and github comments is that the JSON formatter deprecation may have spooked people

David Goss
2021-03-26 15:48:19

*Thread Reply:* (I have a couple projects at work I haven't migrated yet and it's because I have to rework formatters and haven't got it done yet.)

David Goss
2021-03-27 01:31:55

*Thread Reply:* We do also have a bunch unreleased fixes to issues that are probably blockers for some folks e.g. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1516

(Ideally, I'd like to be able to do releases myself.)

travi (https://github.com/travi)
#1516 new unsatisfied peer dependencies with latest verion
<p>i've been receiving renovate PRs for the new v7 in some of my projects now that you've promoted it to latest. i had upgraded a few of my projects to the prerelease of v7 already without issue.</p> <p>however, i'm now seeing some new failures due to unsatisfied peer dependencies with the new version. you can see an example of this in <a href="https://github.com/form8ion/add-package-to-monorepo/pull/40/checks?check_run_id=1591286270#step:5:69">this build output</a>. i use <code>npm ls</code> to ensure that peer dependencies are compatible (it will exit non-zero if there is a conflict).</p> <p>the projects that i'm seeing these issues in are not react projects, so i have no reason to depend on the peer packages other than because of the use of cucumber, so i would prefer not to depend on them directly. could you please satisfy these peer dependencies on your end by making them prod dependencies of cucumber?</p>

*Thread Reply:* FWIW I get this on my host (Node v15.12.0), which looks like the same error as in CI, just with a slightly more informative error message:

TypeError [ERR_UNKNOWN_FILE_EXTENSION]: Unknown file extension ".tsx" for /Users/Aslak.Hellesoy/git/cucumber/cucumber/react/javascript/test/StepTest.tsx at new NodeError (node:internal/errors:329:5) at Loader.defaultGetFormat [as _getFormat] (node:internal/modules/esm/get_format:71:15) at Loader.getFormat (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:102:42) at Loader.getModuleJob (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:231:31) at Loader.import (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:165:17) at importModuleDynamicallyWrapper (node:internal/vm/module:437:15) at formattedImport (/Users/Aslak.Hellesoy/git/cucumber/cucumber/node_modules/mocha/lib/esm-utils.js:7:14) at Object.exports.loadFilesAsync (/Users/Aslak.Hellesoy/git/cucumber/cucumber/node_modules/mocha/lib/esm-utils.js:55:20) at singleRun (/Users/Aslak.Hellesoy/git/cucumber/cucumber/node_modules/mocha/lib/cli/run-helpers.js:125:3) at Object.exports.handler (/Users/Aslak.Hellesoy/git/cucumber/cucumber/node_modules/mocha/lib/cli/run.js:362:5)

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-05-14 04:37:51

*Thread Reply:* After hours of digging, I've found the problem. Upgrading hast-util-sanitize (in react/javascript/package.json from 3.0.2 to 4.0.0 is what breaks this.

In version 4.0.0 that module became ESM only: https://github.com/syntax-tree/hast-util-sanitize#install

From what I understand, that also means the @cucumber/react module must be configured to output ESM. https://gist.github.com/sindresorhus/a39789f98801d908bbc7ff3ecc99d99c#can-i-import-esm-packages-in-my-typescript-project

I suppose more and more npm modules are going to become ESM only, so does it make sense for us to convert all the cucumber/common modules to output ESM too? What kind of problems can this potentially cause our downstream consumers?

syntax-tree/hast-util-sanitize
Website
<https://unifiedjs.com>
Stars
30
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-05-14 05:12:14

*Thread Reply:* Also relevant: https://github.com/sindresorhus/meta/discussions/15

David Goss
2021-05-14 10:22:27

*Thread Reply:* Sorry got sidetracked by work. Node 10 is EOL now so I think in general moving to ESM for our JS packages would be a good thing.

David Goss
2021-05-14 10:27:16

*Thread Reply:* As I understand it, this is a breaking change - if we started just shipping ESM, if people are using those in a non-ESM context (i.e. using require) they'd have to change that code to use import instead (either static or dynamic).

David Goss
2021-05-14 10:28:10

*Thread Reply:* cucumber-js is a less straightforward case because we are loading arbitrary user code that in turns imports/requires our code.

David Goss
2021-05-14 10:29:25

*Thread Reply:* I see you backed out the hast-util-sanitize upgrade from the markdown PR - I'll have a play with that on its own and see where I get. But yes essentially we'd need to change the tsconfig to emit ESM instead of CommonJS then handle that in html-formatter and co.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-05-14 11:07:53

*Thread Reply:* If we were to publish cucumber-js as an ESM module, would projects using TypeScript be able to use it without also being ESM?

My understanding is they wouldn't be...

David Goss
2021-05-15 01:52:52

*Thread Reply:* That's right - they would need to compile their TypeScript down to ESM not CommonJS. This is not yet stable in ts-node https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007 so I think it would be a bit early to make that change. Current plan is to release supporting either as an interim step once we solve a few issues https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1649

<https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007|#1007 ESM support: soliciting feedback>
<a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node">TypeStrong/ts-node</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1649|#1649 cli: ESM take 2>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-05-26 07:31:37

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1573|#1573 Can't use @cucumber/react in Next.js>
<p>We're currently importing CSS from the React components. That gave me an error when using this in a Next.js app (Cucumber Reports):</p> <pre><code>14:11:04.416 | Failed to compile. -- | -- 14:11:04.416 | ../../node_modules/@cucumber/react/dist/src/components/app/GherkinDocumentList.module.scss 14:11:04.417 | CSS Modules cannot be imported from within node_modules. 14:11:04.417 | Read more: &lt;https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/css-modules-npm&gt; 14:11:04.417 | Location: ../../node_modules/@cucumber/react/dist/src/components/app/GherkinDocumentList.js </code></pre> <p>More info here: <a href="https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/css-modules-npm">https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/css-modules-npm</a></p>

<p>Add support for the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber-js</a> test runner.</p> <p>Because literally nobody asked me. Once. Ever.</p> <p>Here it is ✨</p> <p>The <code>@stryker-mutator/cucumber-runner</code> 🎉</p>

<a href="https://github.com/stryker-mutator/stryker-js">stryker-mutator/stryker-js</a>
David Goss
2021-06-28 02:35:01

Wrote up an initial proposal for getting a proper programmatic API into cucumber-js https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711|#1711 Proposal: Programmatic API for running cucumber-js>
<p><strong>Problem</strong></p> <p>Currently we don't have a good way to programmatically run cucumber-js. The need is from two angles:</p> <p>• Testing - for the CCK and our acceptance tests in the project • Projects that use cucumber-js as part of a framework (e.g. Serenity, Stryker)</p> <p><strong>As-is</strong></p> <p>What tends to happen at the moment is a new instance of <code>Cli</code> is created with <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/compatibility/cck_spec.ts#L41">strung-together argv input</a>. It's obviously very unweildy and also <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1710">isn't on the public API</a>.</p> <p>Sometimes (possibly due to perceived fragility of the above) frameworks will just rely on the cucumber-js CLI but struggle to find ways to integrate and have their own options.</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/src/runtime/index.ts#L42"><code>Runtime</code> class</a> is currently part of the public API but it's not useful in these contexts, depending on the pickles and support code to be provided by the caller.</p> <p><strong>Proposal</strong></p> <p>Two components in the project:</p> <p><strong><code>runCucumber</code></strong></p> <p>New async function that executes a test run in-process. Responsibilities:</p> <p>• Accept an options object with a nice interface • Do the "work" of resolving pickles, loading support code, running test cases, orchestrating formatters • Return a promise that resolves to a result</p> <p>This would be part of the public API and we'd encourage framework maintainers to use it when "wrapping" cucumber-js. We'd also use it for our own testing.</p> <p>As much as possible, it would avoid direct interaction with <code>process</code>, instead accepting normalised options and stream interfaces for output, and leaving it to the caller to decide how to exit based on the result or an unhandled error.</p> <p>Also <code>Runtime</code> should come off the public API as it's really an internal thing.</p> <p><strong>CLI</strong></p> <p>Effectively a "client" of <code>runCucumber</code>. Responsibilities:</p> <p>• Parse input from process arguments (via commander) • Load profiles (which as it stands are a feature of the CLI) and mix those arguments in as needed • Call <code>runCucumber</code> with the resolved options • Exit as appropriate based on the results</p> <p>This would continue to <em>not</em> be on the public API. Also it would only use functions/interfaces that <em>are</em> on the public API, such that we could easily break it out into its own package at some point, as is a common pattern now with projects like <a href="https://github.com/facebook/jest/tree/master/packages">Jest</a>.</p> <p>This decoupling also paves the way for some interesting new CLI features without having them bleed into the internals, e.g.:</p> <p>• <code>--gui</code> for the cucumber-electron stuff • <code>--interactive</code> for quick targeted reruns when TDD'ing</p> <p><strong>Timescale</strong></p> <p>We'd target this at the upcoming 8.0.0 release. I'm ready to gets started on this today.</p>
Comments
2
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 03:18:32

@Nico Jansen has joined the channel

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 03:23:04

Q: Is there a way to uninclude feature files?

For example:

// cucumber.js module.exports = { default: 'my-features/**.feature' } And then run with:

$ npx cucumber-js !****/**.feature my-feature/math.feature:7

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:27:47

*Thread Reply:* Interesting - you'd expect that to work, given it should end up as

[ 'my-features/**.feature', '!****/**.feature', 'my-feature/math.feature:7' ]

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:28:26

*Thread Reply:* yes, it ends up like that

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:29:00

*Thread Reply:* I already found it I think: they are globbed 1 by 1:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/4ef971016858bcc3ad5aa3af57439dff5a158277/src/cli/configuration_builder.ts#L125-L141

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/4ef971016858bcc3ad5aa3af57439dff5a158277/src/cli/configuration_builder.ts | configuration_builder.ts>
<pre><code> const expandedPaths = await bluebird.map( unexpandedPaths, async (unexpandedPath) =&amp;gt; { const matches = await promisify(glob)(unexpandedPath, { absolute: true, cwd: this.cwd, }) const expanded = await bluebird.map(matches, async (match) =&amp;gt; { if (path.extname(match) === '') { return await promisify(glob)(`${match}/****/**${defaultExtension}`) } return [match] }) return _.flatten(expanded) } ) return _.flatten(expandedPaths).map((x) =&amp;gt; path.normalize(x)) </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:29:14

*Thread Reply:* So I don't think its possible 😢

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:30:22

*Thread Reply:* I see, good find. I don't think it's out of the question to change that though! Make an issue?

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:30:40

*Thread Reply:* Trying to think about if it would be a breaking change for any usages but I don't think so?

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:33:50

*Thread Reply:* [ 'my-features/**.feature', // --&gt; resolves ['my-features/foo.feature', 'my-features/math.feature'] '!****/**.feature', // --&gt; resolves nothing 'my-feature/math.feature:7' --&gt; resolves ['my-features/math.feature'] ]

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:33:56

*Thread Reply:* As a workaround for your particular case, if you were able to have your features located under just features/ then you wouldn't need the entry against your default profile as it would use the default glob - which is also ignored as soon as you specify any paths

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:34:53

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, but I'm trying to make a generic cucumber-runner plugin for StrykerJS

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:35:11

*Thread Reply:* So I want to use the config of the user

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:35:17

*Thread Reply:* Right, fair enough

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:35:19

*Thread Reply:* but during mutation testing, I want to filter the tests

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:35:39

*Thread Reply:* It is working, except it is also running the feature files that are not inside the test filter

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:36:19

*Thread Reply:* so its running too many tests, which is kind of annoying, might result in a big performance loss depending on the amount of feature files.

Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:36:55

*Thread Reply:* We could add a manual where we ask users to make a stryker profile

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:37:56

*Thread Reply:* I think it's reasonable to do the globbing in one go and have the negation work, I think people familiar with NodeJS command-line tools would expect it to work this way - maybe we need to change libraries to do that e.g. globby . We could put it in the 8.0.0 in case it's breaking for someone (though I still can't think how)

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:38:45

*Thread Reply:* > We could add a manual where we ask users to make a stryker  profile That could be an elegant workaround

David Goss
2021-06-28 04:39:52

*Thread Reply:* Also adds weight to @Aurélien Reeves point here https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711#issuecomment-869542473 - that in the new programmatic API, we might want to add a way to provide a custom pickle filter

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711#issuecomment-869542473|Comment on #1711 Proposal: Programmatic API for running cucumber-js>
<p>While specifying that new public API, we may also consider what recently happened with issue <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1489">#1489</a> and think about providing public APIs to have more and better interaction with the filters and the resulting features under test</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Nico Jansen
2021-06-28 04:41:24

*Thread Reply:* > That could be an elegant workaround Not really, in my experience people don't read manuals 😉

😆 David Goss
matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 07:46:40

*Thread Reply:* @Nico Jansen you can use tags within the Gherkin docs to exclude features - is that any use in this context?

Nico Jansen
2021-07-05 07:52:43

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @matt-SmartBear. That might work as well. I currently have documented it here: https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/stryker-js/cucumber-runner#non-standard-feature-file-locations

stryker-mutator.io
Cucumber Runner | Stryker Mutator
A plugin to use CucumberJS in StrykerJS
Original URL: https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/stryker-js/cucumber-runner#non-standard-feature-file-locations

David Goss
2021-07-01 00:46:58

*Thread Reply:* Off and on. I had thought it was maybe bug that affected PRs that were created before we changed the workflows, but it's happening even on newer ones I think.

Nico Jansen
2021-07-02 13:41:37

https://twitter.com/stryker_mutator/status/1411062223129264128

You can now use Mutation Testing with cucumber-js! 😍

See https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/stryker-js/cucumber-runner/

twitter
Stryker mutation testing 👽 (https://twitter.com/stryker_mutator/status/1411062223129264128)
StrykerJS 5.2 just released 🎉 With more goodness 🎁 ❓ Optional chaining mutator 🥒Support for cucumber-js as a test runner. See <https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/stryker-js/cucumber-runner> Start mutation testing today! <https://stryker-mutator.io> <a href="https://twitter.com/cucumberbdd">@cucumberbdd</a>
Original URL: https://twitter.com/stryker_mutator/status/1411062223129264128
Twitter
stryker-mutator.io
Cucumber Runner | Stryker Mutator
A plugin to use CucumberJS in StrykerJS
Original URL: https://stryker-mutator.io/docs/stryker-js/cucumber-runner/
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-07-03 01:53:10

*Thread Reply:* Very cool @Nico Jansen - been a fan of mutation testing for nearly two decades, but have rarely used it. I’m looking forward to trying StrykerJS on some of our internal projects. We use @cucumber/screenplay on these projects and have plenty of millisecond fast tests, so it should be an excellent fit.

❤️ Nico Jansen
Nico Jansen
2021-07-03 04:17:35

*Thread Reply:* Thanks! I'm wondering how big of a user base this plugin will end up having. The reason for creating it is simple: I needed it 🙂 . We've been moving some domain-level unit tests from mocha to cucumber and I didn't want to give up mutation testing.

Most users probably use cucumber js with some form of browser automation framework, which won't work out of the box with StrykerJS.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-07-03 09:27:50

*Thread Reply:* Yeah it's very common for people to use Cucumber along with browser automation tools. We're trying to educate the community to use Cucumber underneath the UI (or using @cucumber/electron which lets you run the entire app in one process), but this is out of reach for most of our users.

Nico Jansen
2021-07-03 09:38:38

*Thread Reply:* Hmm interesting, as long as the test environment shares it's global variables with the system under test mutation testing will work.

Is @cucumber/electron its own test runner? Or is it using @cucumber/cucumber as it's runner?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-07-03 09:51:05

*Thread Reply:* @cucumber/electron is just a thin wrapper around @cucumber/cucumber that runs Cucumber inside an Electron process so you have access to the DOM.

The entry point is here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-electron/blob/main/src/renderer/main.js

At work we have a couple of Node.js / React apps and we use it to run the server and the UI in the same process. Each scenario runs in about 10-50ms.

We use @cucumber/screenplay to stitch it all togerher - that repo also has an example using @cucumber/electron

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-electron/blob/main/src/renderer/main.js | main.js>
<pre><code>// This is the main entry point for the electron process const { join, resolve } = require('path') const { pathToFileURL } = require('url') const { app, ipcMain: ipc, BrowserWindow } = require('electron') app.commandLine.appendSwitch('--disable-http-cache') const Options = require('../cli/options') const options = new Options(process.argv) global.mainProcessDebug = function ({ namespaces, args }) { const debug = require('debug') debug.inspectOpts.colors = process.env.DEBUG_COLORS || options.isTTY const log = debug(namespaces) log(...args) } let win app.whenReady().then(() =&amp;gt; { win = new BrowserWindow({ height: 900, width: 1000, focusable: options.interactiveMode, show: false, webPreferences: { webSecurity: process.env.CUCUMBER_ELECTRON_DISABLE_WEB_SECURITY !== '1', contextIsolation: false, nodeIntegration: true, enableRemoteModule: true, }, }) win.webContents.once('did-finish-load', () =&amp;gt; { ipc.on('cucumber-run-end', (_, code) =&amp;gt; app.exit(code)) if (!options.interactiveMode) { win.webContents.send('run-cucumber') return } win.show() win.webContents.openDevTools() win.webContents.on('devtools-opened', () =&amp;gt; { // Debugger is not immediately ready setTimeout(() =&amp;gt; { win.webContents.send('run-cucumber') // after the first run, reloading the electron window re-runs cucumber ipc.on('ready-to-run-cucumber', () =&amp;gt; { win.webContents.send('run-cucumber') }) }, 250) }) }) if (!options.interactiveMode &amp;amp;&amp;amp; process.platform === 'darwin') { app.dock.hide() } const url = pathToFileURL(join(__dirname, `index.html`)) if (options.stylesheet) { url.searchParams.set('stylesheet', resolve(options.stylesheet)) } const indexPath = url.href win.loadURL(indexPath) }) // in debug mode electron window stays open after ctrc-c // the code below force quits the window app.on('before-quit', function () { app.exit() }) </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-electron">cucumber/cucumber-electron</a>
Nico Jansen
2021-07-03 11:29:42

*Thread Reply:* That's in interesting approach. Too bad it needs its own entry point, since that would mean a new Stryker plugin is needed. Maybe that is what we can solve with the new API.

I whish there was some sort of universal testrunner API for JavaScript that everyone is using. This is the approach in .NET and Java.

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-05 07:47:25

*Thread Reply:* Super awesome, thanks @Nico Jansen!

❤️ Nico Jansen

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-19 13:05:10

@Aslak Hellesøy @David Goss and insights or thoughts on what might be causing this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1735

@Emmanuel Ola one of the new-contributor mobbers, has a parent directory to his code folder with parentheses in the name, and they're getting stripped out of feature file paths when printed on the console, which breaks a bunch of acceptance tests.

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1735|#1735 Cucumber's own features fail when parent directory contains parentheses>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> Whenever the parent directory has parentheses in its name, I noticed the cucumber features tests start to fail. I also noticed that in the tests that are run, the path for the parent directory drops the parentheses from the path name. For the above reason, the path can not be found for a specified directory.</p> <pre><code>22) Scenario: # features/usage_json_formatter.feature:8 ✔ Before # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 ✔ Given a file named "features/a.feature" with: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 """ Feature: a feature Scenario: a scenario Given step A And step A When step B Then step C """ ✔ And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.js" with: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 """ const {When} = require('@cucumber/cucumber') When('step A', function() {}); When('step B', function() {}); When('step C', function() {}); When(/step D/, function() {}); """ ✔ When I run cucumber-js with `--format usage-json` # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 ✖ Then it outputs the usage data: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 | PATTERN | PATTERN_TYPE | URI | LINE | NUMBER OF MATCHES | | step A | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 3 | 2 | | step B | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 4 | 1 | | step C | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 5 | 1 | | step D | RegularExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 6 | 0 | AssertionError + expected - actual -13 +3 at /Users/emmanuelola/Documents/Cucumber (x)/cucumber-js/features/step_definitions/usage_json_steps.ts:15:30 at Array.forEach (&amp;lt;anonymous&amp;gt;) at World.&amp;lt;anonymous&amp;gt; (/Users/emmanuelola/Documents/Cucumber (x)/cucumber-js/features/step_definitions/usage_json_steps.ts:9:18) ✔ After # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 </code></pre> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <ol><li>Go to 'the root directory for the project'</li><li>Add a parent directory with a parentheses in its name (include some letters within the parentheses)</li><li>Open the project in your desired IDE</li><li>Run the tests</li><li>See error</li> </ol> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong><br /> Passing tests</p> <p><strong>Screenshots</strong><br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54866720/126218939-c2815926-79e2-4b3e-9af5-0bf987e8598f.png">Untitled</a></p> <p><strong>Desktop (please complete the following information):</strong></p> <p>• OS: macOS Big Sur 11.4 • Version: Main Repository Branch</p> <p><strong>Additional context</strong><br /> Trying to run tests to contribute to cucumber-js with <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> as part of the Cucumber first timers mob and the folder where I keep my code happens to have parentheses in its name. For more context, this is not the folder shown in the screenshot, that's simply provided for testing purposes.</p>

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-23 08:06:33

Is there a reason we don't use tsc --build in cucumber-js? Running the tests seems slow, and I know that's one optimisation you can use to speed up TypeScript compilation.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-07-23 11:04:49

*Thread Reply:* I’ve been wondering the same.

David Goss
2021-07-23 11:37:39

*Thread Reply:* Is this for the meta-tests? Do you mean for compiling the source code, test code or both?

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-23 12:07:33

*Thread Reply:* when I run yarn test I see it running tcs commands that don't have --build in them, meaning it's compiling the typescript over and over.

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1735|#1735 Cucumber's own features fail when parent directory contains parentheses>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> Whenever the parent directory has parentheses in its name, I noticed the cucumber features tests start to fail. I also noticed that in the tests that are run, the path for the parent directory drops the parentheses from the path name. For the above reason, the path can not be found for a specified directory.</p> <pre><code>22) Scenario: # features/usage_json_formatter.feature:8 ✔ Before # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 ✔ Given a file named "features/a.feature" with: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 """ Feature: a feature Scenario: a scenario Given step A And step A When step B Then step C """ ✔ And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.js" with: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 """ const {When} = require('@cucumber/cucumber') When('step A', function() {}); When('step B', function() {}); When('step C', function() {}); When(/step D/, function() {}); """ ✔ When I run cucumber-js with `--format usage-json` # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 ✖ Then it outputs the usage data: # ../../Cucumber x/cucumber-js/src/support_code_library_builder/build_helpers.ts:13 | PATTERN | PATTERN_TYPE | URI | LINE | NUMBER OF MATCHES | | step A | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 3 | 2 | | step B | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 4 | 1 | | step C | CucumberExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 5 | 1 | | step D | RegularExpression | features/step_definitions/steps.js | 6 | 0 | AssertionError + expected - actual -13 +3 at /Users/emmanuelola/Documents/Cucumber (x)/cucumber-js/features/step_definitions/usage_json_steps.ts:15:30 at Array.forEach (&amp;lt;anonymous&amp;gt;) at World.&amp;lt;anonymous&amp;gt; I spent some time trying to upgrade react-markdown and its plugins rehype-sanitize, rehype-raw and remark-gfm.

I made small progress but there are still some errors. Could anyone have a look on this?

https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1693

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1693|#1693 Update dependency react-markdown to v7>
<p><a href="https://renovatebot.com">WhiteSource Renovate</a></p> <p>This PR contains the following updates:</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Release Notes</strong> remarkjs/react-markdown <strong><a href="https://togithub.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/blob/master/changelog.md#%E2%80%8B700---2021-08-13|&lt;code">https://togithub.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/blob/master/changelog.md#%E2%80%8B700---2021-08-13|<code</a>v7.0.0</code>&gt;</strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/compare/6.0.3...7.0.0">Compare Source</a></p> <p>Welcome to version 7.<br /> This a major release and therefore contains breaking changes.</p> <p><strong>Breaking changes</strong></p> <p>• <a href="https://togithub.com/remarkjs/react-markdown/commit/01b11fe"><code>01b11fe</code></a><br /> <a <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-24 07:39:26

*Thread Reply:* @Aurélien Reeves the new versions of some of these libraries are ESM-only, so I think we need to bite the bullet and update all the monorepo js modules to be ESM modules too...

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-24 07:39:32

*Thread Reply:* I'll have a crack at that.

👍 Aurélien Reeves
Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-24 07:45:13

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Aslak Hellesøy Indeed I think ESM is related to the issue

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-24 07:46:45

*Thread Reply:* We may need to get rid of ts-node: their ESM support is still experimental, and not great at the moment: https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007

<https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007|#1007 ESM support: soliciting feedback>
<p>Please use this ticket to provide feedback on our native ESM support, which is currently experimental. Your involvement is greatly appreciated to ensure the feature works on real-world projects.</p> <p><strong>Experimental warning</strong></p> <p><a href="https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#esm_experimental_loaders">Node's loader hooks</a> are <strong>EXPERIMENTAL</strong> and subject to change. ts-node's ESM support is also experimental. They are likely to have breaking changes in the near future. You have been warned!</p> <p><strong>Usage</strong> <strong>Requirements</strong></p> <p>• Set <code>"module": "ESNext"</code> or <code>"ES2015"</code> so that TypeScript emits import/export syntax. • Set <code>"type": "module"</code> in your <code>package.json</code>, which is required to tell node that .js files are ESM instead of CommonJS. To be compatible with editors, the compiler, and the TypeScript ecosystem, we cannot name our source files <code>.mts</code> nor <code>.mjs</code>. • Install ts-node locally, not globally. <code>npm install ts-node</code> or <code>yarn add ts-node</code> • Include file extensions in your <code>import</code> statements, or pass <code>--experimental-specifier-resolution=node</code> Idiomatic TypeScript should import <code>foo.ts</code> as <code>import 'foo.js';</code> TypeScript understands this. • The language service accepts configuration to include the file extension in automatically-written imports. In VSCode:<br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/376504/80899399-a3ae6d80-8cdd-11ea-85ea-b19151dad841.png">image</a></p> <p><strong>Invocation</strong></p> <pre><code>node --loader ts-node/esm ./my-script.ts # To force the use of a specific tsconfig.json, use the TS_NODE_PROJECT environment variable TS_NODE_PROJECT="path/to/tsconfig.json" node --loader ts-node/esm ./my-script.ts </code></pre> <p>You must invoke <code>node</code> directly because there is no way for us to enable our loader hook at runtime. Be aware this imposes some limitations on our implementation.</p> <p><strong>Configuration</strong></p> <p>tsconfig will be resolved relative to <code>process.cwd()</code>. Specify ts-node options in your tsconfig file. For details, see our <a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node#options-via-tsconfigjson">README</a>.</p> <p>ts-node CLI flags are not parsed, but environment variables <em>are</em> parsed. You can use <code>TS_NODE_PROJECT</code> to tell ts-node to use a specific tsconfig, and you can put all other ts-node options into this config file.</p> <p><strong>Versioning</strong></p> <p>During this experimental phase, all changes to ESM support, including breaking changes, will be released as minor or patch versions, <em>NOT</em> major versions. This conforms to semantic versioning's philosophy for version numbers lower than 1.0. Stable features will continue to be versioned as normal.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Pending development work</strong></p> <p>☐ Make resolution lookup use our fs caches ☐ Create esm-script.mjs to do --script-mode? • Can read <code>process.argv</code> for config resolution? ☑︎ Implement <code>require('ts-node').esmImport(module, 'import-path')</code> • use <a href="https://npm.im/tsimportlib">https://npm.im/tsimportlib</a> ☑︎ Throw error when CJS attempts to require ESM, matching node's behavior for .js • See below: "Changes to existing functionality" &gt; "require() hook"</p> <p><strong>The proposal</strong></p> <p>Below is the official proposal, explaining our implementation in detail.</p> <hr /> <p><em>I am asking node's modules team questions here: <a href="https://github.com/nodejs/modules/issues/351">nodejs/modules#351</a></em></p> <p>I was reading the threads about ESM support in ts-node, e.g. #935.</p> <p>The @K-FOSS/TS-ESNode implementation is unfortunately incomplete; it does not attempt to typecheck. (it uses transpileModule)</p> <p>So I did some research. Below is a proposal for ESM support in <code>ts-node</code>, describing the required behavior in detail.</p> <p>This doesn't feel like an urgent feature to me, but I like having an official proposal we can work on.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Usage</strong></p> <pre><code>node --loader ts-node/esm ./entrypoint.ts </code></pre> <p>Cannot be invoked as <code>ts-node</code> because it requires node flags; hooks cannot be enabled at runtime. This is unavoidable.</p> <p>For simplicity, <code>--require ts-node/register</code> can be eliminated, because <code>ts-node/esm</code> automatically does that.</p> <p>Alternatively, we publish an experimental <code>ts-node-esm</code> entry-point which invokes a <code>node</code> subprocess.</p> <hr /> <p>Don't forget <code>allowJs</code>! Affects the treatment of <code>.js</code> files. (Not <code>.mjs</code> nor <code>.cjs</code> because the TS language service won't look at them)</p> <p><strong>ESM hooks</strong></p> <p>Must implement ESM hooks to resolve extensionless imports to .ts files, resolve .js to .ts, classify .ts(x) and .jsx files as CJS or MJS, and compile .ts(x) and .jsx files.</p> <p><strong><code>resolve()</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>Match additional file extensions: <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, <code>.jsx</code>.</p> <p>Resolve <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, and <code>.jsx</code> if the import specifier says <code>.js</code>. Obey preferTsExts when doing this.</p> <p>_</p> <p>[Good idea?] Always ask default resolver first. If it finds something, we should not interfere.</p> <p><code>--experimental-specifier-resolution=node</code> does <em>not</em> obey <code>require.extensions</code>, unfortunately, so we can't use that.</p> <p><strong><code>getFormat</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>If the resolved file is <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, or <code>.jsx</code>, behave as if extension was <code>.js</code>: use node's <code>package.json</code> discovery behavior to figure out if ESM or CJS.</p> <p>This can be accomplished by appending <code>.js</code> to the URL path and delegating to built-in <code>getFormat</code> hook.</p> <p><strong><code>transformSource</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>Same as today's code transformer. Relies on projects to be configured correctly for <code>import</code>/<code>export</code> emit.</p> <p><strong>Changes to existing functionality</strong> <strong><code>require()</code> hook</strong></p> <p>• Use same <code>getFormat</code> logic to determine if node will treat file as CJS or ESM. • NOTE node already detects and throws some errors on its own. But if <code>require.resolve</code> points to a <code>.ts</code> file, we need to make the determination. • If ESM, throw the same error as NodeJS ("cannot load ESM via require()") • copying logic from <a href="https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/38998d85384f85fd36fb478d20557d80de886949/lib/internal/modules/cjs/loader.js#L1184-L1197">node's source here</a></p> <p><strong><code>require()</code> code transform</strong></p> <p>• Must somehow allow <code>import()</code> calls. • Force consumers to use <code>require('ts-node').esmImport(module, 'import-path')</code>?</p> <p><strong><code>ts-node</code> bin entry-point</strong></p> <p><code>ts-node</code> CLI does <em>NOT</em> need to support <code>import()</code>ing ESM.</p> <p>WHY? Because ESM hooks are an experimental feature which <em>must</em> be enabled via node CLI flag.</p> <p>Thus we will be loaded via <code>--require</code>, and Node is responsible for loading the entry-point, either triggering our hook or our <code>require.extensions</code>.</p> <p><strong>Allow <code>import()</code> in CJS</strong></p> <p>If <code>"module": "commonjs"</code>, compiler transforms <code>import()</code> into <code>__importStar</code></p> <p>No way to change this without a custom transformer, which IMO is too much complexity at this time.</p> <p>Users should run their code as ESM.</p> <p>If they can't do that, we can recommend the following workaround:</p> <pre><code>// This is in a CommonJS file: const dynamicallyImportedEsmModule = await require('ts-node').importESM('./specifier-of-esm-module', module); </code></pre> <p><strong>Emit considerations</strong></p> <p><em>NOTE we have not implemented the following, although initially I thought we might. Instead, we assume tsconfig is configured for either ESM or CJS as needed</em></p> <p>We could intelligently emit both <code>"module": "esnext"</code> and <code>"module": "commonjs"</code> depending on the classification of a file.</p> <p>In <code>transpile-only</code> mode this is simple. Call <code>transpileModule</code> with different options.</p> <p>When typechecking, we can pull <code>SourceFile</code> ASTs from the language service / incremental compiler.</p> <p>We'll need a second compiler, one for each emit format. Or we can hack it by using <code>transpileModule</code> for all ESM output. <code>transpileModule</code> is incompatible with certain kinds of TS code, (can't do const enums) but it might work for a first-pass implementation.</p>
Labels
enhancement, research

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-25 02:38:44

*Thread Reply:* We only use ts-node in development to avoid having to pre-compile all the ts code in the repo. My understanding is that the ESM support is experimental because Node.js own ESM support is experimental.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-25 02:39:44

*Thread Reply:* I think I've found a way to make ts-node work with ESM. I'll commit something soon.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-25 03:12:16

*Thread Reply:* @Aurélien Reeves see https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1709 for a draft PR

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1709|#1709 ESM modules>
<p>This PR is an attempt to switch to ESM modules. The motivation for doing this is than an increasing number of npm modules are NPM only, and we cannot use them unless our own modules are ESM.</p> <p>In order to be able to import e.g. <code>@cucumber/messages</code> from <code>@cucumber/message-streams</code> (inter-module dependencies) at runtime (using ts-node so we don't need to pre-compile all ts code), we can no longer depend on <a href="https://github.com/dividab/tsconfig-paths">tsconfig-paths</a>.</p> <p>Instead, I have written a custom ESM loader that extends the <code>ts-node/esm</code> loader and modifies code like <code>import from '@cucumber/messages'</code> to <code>import from '@cucumber/messages/typescript'</code>. This works as long as all our modules export a <code>./typescript</code> module in the package.json <code>exports</code> section.</p> <p>There are still some issues to sort out, but I've got this working for the <code>@cucumber/messages</code> and <code>@cucumber/message-streams</code> modules.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-25 05:17:07

*Thread Reply:* > We only use ts-node in development to avoid having to pre-compile all the ts code in the repo. My understanding is that the ESM support is experimental because Node.js own ESM support is experimental. In node.js documentation, they indicates that ESM support is not experimental anymore, it has reached the stability level "Stable" for all LTS version since 12: https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v12.x/api/esm.html

Maybe we could also consider using tsc --build instead of ts-node? That may be simpler for the moment?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-25 05:40:24

*Thread Reply:* > In node.js documentation, they indicates that ESM support is not experimental anymore I meant the loader API: https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v12.x/api/esm.html#esm_experimental_loaders

> Maybe we could also consider using tsc --build instead of ts-node? If we did that, how would you run a mocha test?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-25 06:05:34

*Thread Reply:* Using Babel? 😅😇:partyparrot:

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 02:59:18

Hi @Aurélien Reeves - let's chat here rather than in https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1709 🙂

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1709|#1709 ESM modules>
<p>This PR is an attempt to switch to ESM modules. The motivation for doing this is than an increasing number of npm modules are ESM only, and we cannot use them unless our own modules are ESM.</p> <p>In order to be able to import e.g. <code>@cucumber/messages</code> from <code>@cucumber/message-streams</code> (inter-module dependencies) at runtime (using ts-node so we don't need to pre-compile all ts code), we can no longer depend on <a href="https://github.com/dividab/tsconfig-paths">tsconfig-paths</a>.</p> <p>Instead, I have written a custom ESM loader that extends the <code>ts-node/esm</code> loader and modifies code like <code>import from '@cucumber/messages'</code> to <code>import from '@cucumber/messages/typescript'</code>. This works as long as all our modules export a <code>./typescript</code> module in the package.json <code>exports</code> section.</p> <p>There are still some issues to sort out, but I've got this working for the <code>@cucumber/messages</code> and <code>@cucumber/message-streams</code> modules.</p>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 02:59:57

In your last comment - what do you mean when you say it should not be a side-effect of something else?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:02:32

*Thread Reply:* The objective of the PR is to convert javascript packages into ESM modules.

Impacting the APIs would be a side effect, not a choice, not by design, but a side effect

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 03:03:36

*Thread Reply:* Are you saying we can convert modules to ESM without impacting the APIs?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:04:43

*Thread Reply:* Maybe, yes. It may be possible to export everything as before, and the typescript ones in bonus

And if it is not possible, maybe we should wait before converting modules to ESM

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 03:06:10

*Thread Reply:* We could export everything as before by listing every single file in the module in exports in package.json. But why would we do that?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:06:31

*Thread Reply:* To avoid breaking changes

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 03:07:09

*Thread Reply:* For whom?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:08:08

*Thread Reply:* For third-party developers who rely on some of our packages

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 03:08:55

*Thread Reply:* The libraries would get a major bump, so I don't see the problem. At some point we have to bite the bullet and be explicit about what our supported APIs are.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:13:57

*Thread Reply:* Breaking changes requires deprecation notices.

And yes, it would be a good point to properly design and document what is public API and what is for our own internal use.

My suggestion is: let's work on APIs first, in dedicated PRs and issues. On a per-module basis, not everything into a single PR which is then difficult to review. As part of that work, or after that, maybe the conversion into ESM modules will then be easier.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:15:12

*Thread Reply:* That would be more granular and more people could be involved. It would be easier to document too.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 03:16:41

*Thread Reply:* It would take more time But it would force us to think more on what would need to be done.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 04:14:55

*Thread Reply:* > Breaking changes requires deprecation notices. Not necessarily - it's up to us. We're talking about libraries that aren't widely used except by Cucumber.js.

I'm not even sure what we would deprecate. Let's discuss around a concrete example - the @cucumber/cucumber-expressions module. What would need to be deprecated here before we release it as ESM?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-26 04:17:16

*Thread Reply:* Regarding your suggesting to work on APIs first. What does that mean in practice for CommonJS modules?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-26 05:34:55

*Thread Reply:* > I'm not even sure what we would deprecate That's the point: we are not sure of anything. Could we take some time to take a step back and think about what we need and what users may need, maybe on a per-module basis - before going deeper in the rabbit hole?

> Regarding your suggesting to work on APIs first. What does that mean in practice for CommonJS modules? What do you mean?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-09-16 07:59:56

Following the community meeting, I open the discussion here regarding setDefinitionFunctionWrapper

My suggestion is to try to rewrite the hook without generators. I may try next week, but not sure I will be able to do it by myself 😅

David Goss
2021-09-16 08:04:01

*Thread Reply:* For reference here is the PR we are talking about:

David Goss
2021-09-16 08:04:03

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1795

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1795|#1795 Revert "remove support for generators (#1725)">
<p>This reverts commit <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/commit/a2dcce6a45dd20bf7a52def5ea9b5f4a3743a642">a2dcce6</a>.</p> <p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>As discussed at our last community meeting, we may need to discuss the removal of setDefinitionFunctionWrapper if we cannot find a workaround to help folks from <a href="http://webdriver.io">webdriver.io</a>: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1772">#1772</a></p>
Comments
7
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
David Goss
2021-09-16 08:04:13

*Thread Reply:* cc @Aslak Hellesøy @matt-SmartBear @Mona Ghassemi

David Goss
2021-09-16 08:05:39

*Thread Reply:* TLDR:

• We deprecated this feature because BeforeStep/AfterStep hooks were introduced, which we believed were the only reason users needed it • We removed the feature on main (not released yet) • Some users (issues linked in PR) flagged that they in fact rely on this and can't do what they need with the new hooks

David Goss
2021-09-16 08:07:07

*Thread Reply:* It seems like the folks who want this to stay are mostly building frameworks (open source or proprietary) that use cucumber. We have historically not made things easy for this group (part of the motivation for the new JS API) and so taking another step backwards would seem bad.

David Goss
2021-09-16 08:09:28

*Thread Reply:* Equally I want to move forward and not have this hold up an 8.x.x release candidate. I'd propose we do what @Aurélien Reeves suggests, which is to re-add the feature (but hopefully in a slimmed-down way) and keep it deprecated. If we then get an understanding of the outstanding use cases and can cater for them another way, we can remove this feature in 9.x.x which probably isn't that far away anyway.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-09-16 08:11:44

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for all the details @David Goss 👌

👍 David Goss
David Goss
2021-09-20 17:10:38

*Thread Reply:* If no objections, I'm going to interpret silence as assent 🙂

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-09-20 23:25:02

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the writeup @David Goss - agree 100%

David Goss
2021-09-27 08:36:51

@Aslak Hellesøy any thoughts/objections on this one before I merge? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1801

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1801|#1801 debt: remove --predictable-ids option>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>• Remove the CLI option for <code>--predictable-ids</code> and related plumbing • Make changes to fixture-based tests to ignore fields that will change on every run, as we do in the CCK tests (reusing the same list of keys)</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>We added predictable timestamps and identifiers at a time where we envisaged checking these values in the CCK so that all implementations would behave the same in this regard.</p> <p>In practise, that level of parity was not practically achievable and so we now exclude timestamps and identifiers when validating against the CCK. Therefore it makes sense to remove this option and related complexity in the codebase.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)</p> <p>(Technically a breaking change but there would be no sense in using this option except for our own testing. At any rate, it's going to be in a major version bump anyway.)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ My code follows the code style of this project. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☑︎ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☑︎ All new and existing tests passed.</p>
Labels
🏦 debt

2021-10-12 03:00:21

cucumber/suggest
Library for suggesting steps
Language
TypeScript
Last updated
2 minutes ago
David Goss
2021-10-13 03:22:57

*Thread Reply:* Okay I think I see the issue. If you use require-module then we take that as a heuristic that we should use require to load the support code rather than import. Looking at your code i see you've done the transpiler setup in a file that you require

David Goss
2021-10-13 03:23:38

*Thread Reply:* So we probably need to update the logic there. Maybe based on the file extension?

David Goss
2021-10-13 03:24:58

*Thread Reply:* eg if the extension isn't one of js, cjs or mjs then we know import isn't right so fall back to require

David Goss
2021-10-16 03:46:19

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak Hellesøy give this a try? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1819

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1819|#1819 esm: fall back to require where file doesnt have a native js extension>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>Don't use <code>import</code> - and instead fall back to <code>require</code> - if the file extension is not a native JavaScript one (meaning <code>import</code> would not be able to handle it in any case).</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>Generally when using a transpiler, it's activated via <code>--require-module</code> which we then use as a heuristic to use <code>require</code> instead of <code>import</code> - however users sometimes just have their transpiler setup in a file that is <code>--require</code>'d - e.g. when passing a custom tsconfig to ts-node.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☑︎ My code follows the code style of this project. ☑︎ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>
Labels
🐛 bug
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-18 04:19:47

Any objections is I make an 8.0.0-rc.1 release today?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-10-18 04:47:36

*Thread Reply:* I agree

We would just have to change the milestone for https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711 from 8.0.0 to 9.0.0 but I think we can start thinking about releasing 8.0. There are already a lot of changes in it, and we can then work on the API for 9.0

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711|#1711 Proposal: Programmatic API for running cucumber-js>
<p><strong>Problem</strong></p> <p>Currently we don't have a good way to programmatically run cucumber-js. The need is from two angles:</p> <p>• Testing cucumber-js - for the CCK and our acceptance tests in the project • Testing custom formatters and snippets • Projects that use cucumber-js as part of a framework (e.g. Serenity, Stryker)</p> <p><strong>As-is</strong></p> <p>What tends to happen at the moment is a new instance of <code>Cli</code> is created with <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/compatibility/cck_spec.ts#L41">strung-together argv input</a>. It's obviously very unweildy and also <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1710">isn't on the public API</a>.</p> <p>Sometimes (possibly due to perceived fragility of the above) frameworks will just rely on the cucumber-js CLI but struggle to find ways to integrate and have their own options.</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/src/runtime/index.ts#L42"><code>Runtime</code> class</a> is currently part of the public API but it's not useful in these contexts, depending on the pickles and support code to be provided by the caller.</p> <p><strong>Proposal</strong></p> <p>Two components in the project:</p> <p><strong><code>runCucumber</code></strong></p> <p>New async function that executes a test run in-process. Responsibilities:</p> <p>• Accept an options object with a nice interface • Do the "work" of resolving pickles, loading support code, running test cases, orchestrating formatters • Return a promise that resolves to a result</p> <p>This would be part of the public API and we'd encourage framework maintainers to use it when "wrapping" cucumber-js. We'd also use it for our own testing.</p> <p>As much as possible, it would avoid direct interaction with <code>process</code>, instead accepting normalised options and stream interfaces for output, and leaving it to the caller to decide how to exit based on the result or an unhandled error.</p> <p>Also <code>Runtime</code> should come off the public API as it's really an internal thing.</p> <p><strong>CLI</strong></p> <p>Effectively a "client" of <code>runCucumber</code>. Responsibilities:</p> <p>• Aggregate options from various sources (argv, env vars, config files) (see <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1711#issuecomment-871329827">comment</a>) • Call <code>runCucumber</code> with the resolved options • Exit as appropriate based on the results</p> <p>This would continue to <em>not</em> be on the public API. Also it would only use functions/interfaces that <em>are</em> on the public API, such that we could easily break it out into its own package at some point, as is a common pattern now with projects like <a href="https://github.com/facebook/jest/tree/master/packages">Jest</a>.</p> <p>This decoupling also paves the way for some interesting new CLI features without having them bleed into the internals, e.g.:</p> <p>• <code>--gui</code> for the cucumber-electron stuff • <code>--interactive</code> for quick targeted reruns when TDD'ing</p> <p><strong>etc</strong></p> <p>We would also expose functions (consumable by the CLI and by others) for:</p> <p>• Getting the options • Handling <code>i18nKeywords</code> and <code>i18nLanguages</code></p> <p><strong>Timescale</strong></p> <p>We'd target this at the upcoming 8.0.0 release.</p>
Assignees
davidjgoss
Labels
💔 breaking change, ⚡ enhancement

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 01:31:28

I've just release 8.0.0-rc.1 using the new GitHub Actions release process: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/RELEASING.md

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/RELEASING.md | RELEASING.md>
<p><strong>Releasing</strong></p> <p>First, update as many dependencies as you can and test:</p> <pre><code>npm run update-dependencies npm test </code></pre> <p>If the tests fail, update your code to be compatible with the new libraries, or<br /> revert the library upgrades that break the build.</p> <p>• Add missing entries to <code>CHANGELOG.md</code> • Ideally the CHANGELOG should be up-to-date, but sometimes there will be accidental omissions when merging PRs. Missing PRs should be added. • Describe the major changes introduced. API changes must be documented. In particular, backward-incompatible changes must be well explained, with examples when possible. • <code>git log --format=format:"** %s (%an)" --reverse &amp;lt;last-version-tag&amp;gt;..HEAD</code> might be handy. • Update the contributors list in <code>package.json</code> • <code>git log --format=format:"%an &amp;lt;%ae&amp;gt;" --reverse &amp;lt;last-version-tag&amp;gt;..HEAD | grep -vEi "(renovate|dependabot|Snyk)" | sort| uniq -i</code> • Manually add contributors (in alphabetical order)</p> <p>Follow <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/blob/main/RELEASING.md">cucumber/.github/RELEASING.md</a><br /> for the rest of the release process.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-10-19 08:53:02

*Thread Reply:* Do you think we could automate away the need to run the update-dependencies script during a release? Maybe have a nightly job that does it into a PR or something?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 12:57:38

*Thread Reply:* I'd prefer to tune Renovate to do it more frequently. Why reinvent the wheel?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 12:58:23

*Thread Reply:* If you want to spend time on this you could start by looking at what's available in the marketplace: https://github.com/marketplace?category=dependency-management

matt-SmartBear
2021-10-19 15:12:12

*Thread Reply:* Yeah even better to just lean on renovate

matt-SmartBear
2021-10-19 15:12:22

*Thread Reply:* It just seems messy to do that at the last minute when you're about to do a release.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 02:01:14

While doing the release I discovered that several pull requests have been merged to main without a mention in CHANGELOG.md - let's try to update CHANGELOG.md when we merge PRs. Or better - encourage contributors to do it as part of their PRs.

mpkorstanje
2021-10-19 02:17:37

*Thread Reply:* Psst:

Squash merge and put a clear title on the PR. Makes updating the change log ad-hoc much easier. 😄

mpkorstanje
2021-10-19 02:18:15

*Thread Reply:* Updating the changelog while an PR is in progress is prone to conflicts.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 05:21:52

*Thread Reply:* I like the suggestion to change the PR title! You're right that updating the changelog in a PR often leads to conflicts - but they tend to be single-line conflicts that are trivial to resolve.

The reason I'm suggesting updating changelog in the PR is that people tend to forget to update the changelog when they merge a PR (as we have seen)

mpkorstanje
2021-10-19 05:23:07

*Thread Reply:* > but they tend to be single-line conflicts that are trivial to resolve. It's a round trip to the contributor.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-10-19 05:26:55

*Thread Reply:* Not necessarily. I tend to click the "Update the pr branch" button on GitHub and resolve any changelog conflicts manually. It's on me, not them.

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-26 12:41:05

I tried onboarding a new contributor on Windows today and we hit a snag:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1852

Is anyone else here using Windows for hacking on cucumber-js and could give us some advice? I'm a bit out of my depth, I haven't used Windows in a long time.

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1852|#1852 Feature Tests Failing on Windows>
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong><br /> While pairing with <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> to set up my development environment, we found that the scenarios all failed. Same error:</p> <pre><code>293) Scenario: custom world constructor is passed the parameters # features\world_parameters.feature:76 × Before # features\support\hooks.ts:20 Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, symlink 'C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber-js' -&amp;gt; 'C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber-js\tmp\world_parameters.feature_76\node_modules\@cucumber\cucumber' at Object.symlinkSync (fs.js:1210:3) at Object.createSymlinkSync (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\node_modules\fs_extra\lib\ensure\symlink.js:76:13) at World.&amp;lt;anonymous&amp;gt; (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\features\support\hooks.ts:42:11) at Object.run (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\user_code_runner.ts:37:21) at Object.run (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\runtime\step_runner.ts:50:41) at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:95:5) at async TestCaseRunner.invokeStep (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\runtime\test_case_runner.ts:130:12) at async TestCaseRunner.runHook (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\runtime\test_case_runner.ts:246:12) at async C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\runtime\test_case_runner.ts:201:20 at async TestCaseRunner.aroundTestStep (C:\Users\gugwu\Documents\OSContribution\cucumber_js\src\runtime\test_case_runner.ts:162:28) - Given a file named "features/passing_steps.feature" with: # features\step_definitions\file_steps.ts:10 """ Feature: a feature Scenario: a scenario Given the world parameters are correct """ - Given a file named "features/support/world.js" with: # features\step_definitions\file_steps.ts:10 """ const {setWorldConstructor} = require('@cucumber/cucumber') function CustomWorld(options) { for(const key in options.parameters) { this[key] = options.parameters[key] } } setWorldConstructor(CustomWorld) """ - Given a file named "features/step_definitions/my_steps.js" with: # features\step_definitions\file_steps.ts:10 """ const assert = require('assert') const {Given} = require('@cucumber/cucumber') Given(/^the world parameters are correct$/, function() { assert.equal(this.a, 1) }) """ - When I run cucumber-js with `--world-parameters '{"a":1}'` # features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:19 - Then scenario "a scenario" step "Given the world parameters are correct" has status "passed" # features\step_definitions\message_steps.ts:68 √ After # features\support\hooks.ts:104 </code></pre> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <ol><li>Open the repo on a Windows machine</li><li>Open the git bash prompt</li><li>Run <code>npm install</code></li><li>Run <code>npm test</code></li> </ol> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong><br /> I expected all the tests to pass.</p> <p><strong>Desktop (please complete the following information):</strong></p> <p>• : Windows 10 build 19042</p>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
mpkorstanje
2021-11-29 00:52:14

*Thread Reply:* Not a windows user, but you can't symlink on windows

mpkorstanje
2021-11-29 00:52:41

*Thread Reply:* Either replace it with a copy operation or ignore the test on windows

Michael Morris
2021-12-01 06:06:31

*Thread Reply:* Note - Windows has a symlink equivalent, but processes using it must have elevated privileges or the OS must be in dev mode. Git can simulate symlinks using this feature, but these psuedo symlinks are applied during checkout.

matt-SmartBear
2021-12-01 11:31:26

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Michael Morris - @Aurélien Reeves taught me about Developer Mode today. We've added this fix which should make it a bit easier for the next person who bumps into this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1863

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1863|#1863 Add a warning for Windows developers who don't have Developer Mode enabled>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>Adds a try/catch block around a line in our <code>features/support_code</code> that creates a symlink. If you're using Windows, unless you have enabled "Developer Mode" this line throws an error.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>The features won't run if you don't have "Developer Mode" enabled. See <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1852">#1852</a></p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)</p> <p><em>Remember to add an entry to the relevant section of CHANGELOG.md as part of this pull request.</em></p> <p><strong>Note to other contributors</strong></p> <p><em>If your change may impact future contributors, explain it here, and remember to update README.md and CONTRIBUTING.md accordingly.</em></p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☑︎ My code follows the code style of this project. ☐ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☑︎ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>

<p>Actually your cucumber.js file is working as a module because of your hack.</p> <p>Your hack load cucumber itself as a module, which it is not. I would encourage you to try removing your hack and using a .cjs file for the configuration. Everything else should work properly using esm imports / exports.</p>

matt-SmartBear
2021-12-10 10:33:38

I've noticed that my VSCode setup doesn't play nicely with out eslint / prettier config, and I can't work out if it's me or our config.

My default setup is to lean on prettier for formatting:

"[typescript]": { "editor.formatOnSave": true, "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode" }, However this doesn't work in cucumber-js. The file ends up being reformatted to a shape that fails a bunch of eslint rules!

I've ended up having to use npm run lint-autofix a lot and disable format-on-save. @Emmanuel Ola has had the same problem.

From some investigation, I think that the options are to either:

  1. move the prettier config out of the .eslintrc.yml into a .prettierrc file so that the prettier plugin for VSCode can see it.
  2. change my workspace settings to use ESLint for formatting typescript files in this project. What are other people doing? I wanted to get some feedback before I go and make a PR or change to the config. I don't want to break anything that's working for other people!
matt-SmartBear
2022-01-04 20:54:02

*Thread Reply:* @David Goss I'd appreciate your thoughts on this

David Goss
2022-01-05 00:49:05

*Thread Reply:* I think you’re right on the situation and the options. Currently I have WebStorm (I don’t use VSCode) set to run eslint --fix on save which works. If we’re able to split out the prettier config to the standard file then that seems like a plus for ease of onboarding though.

👍:skin_tone_2: matt-SmartBear

2022-01-05 00:49:27

type checking for <code>node.source</code> (<a href="https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues/4196">#​4196</a>) (<a asynciterable as an await (<a href="https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues/4125">#​4125</a>) (<a [member-ordering] add option to sort case insensitive (<a href="https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues/3896">#​3896</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/commit/e3533d5a6293a358b5eb0a6ed17da961a09b0ed3">e3533d5</a>) • <strong>eslint-plugin:</strong> <code>array-type</code> distinguish
