Aslak Hellesøy
2022-01-11 03:32:50

@Aurélien Reeves I've done some more work on the language server - adding tests! https://github.com/cucumber/language-server/pull/20

This should make it a lot easier to maintain. Let me know when you want to pair on this.

<https://github.com/cucumber/language-server/pull/20|#20 Acceptance test for textDocument/completion requests>
<p>This adds an acceptance test for the <a href="https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-3-17/#textDocument_completion">textDocument/completion</a> request.</p> <p>It does so by setting up a client and a server (communicating over in-process streams), and then sending requests from the client to the server. (This pattern can be used to test other parts of the server too).</p> <p>To test this, we have to build the index that powers the auto completion. This is done by indexing typescript and gherkin sources. There is a new <code>Settings</code> type for configuring the server, and a corresponding settings screen must be built in the vscode extension.</p> <p>The new test runs with <code>npm run test:cjs</code>, but it doesn't run in esm mode. This is because the import from <code>vscode-jsonrpc/node</code> in <code>CucumberLanguageServer.test.ts</code> doesn't work with esm (it's not a declared export in the module).<br /> I think we should consider making the language server a non-esm module - I don't think it needs to be.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-server">cucumber/language-server</a>
Michael Morris
2022-01-17 08:44:06

This week I can set aside time to go through docs and add some clarifications to help others on the things that have snagged me. How should I split this up issue ticket wise? One large issue for all the changes, or by subject?

:dancing_pickle: Jo Laing
matt-SmartBear
2022-01-17 10:05:24

*Thread Reply:* It's probably useful to make one big ticket for the overall project to give context. You can use a checklist in that ticket to map out the smaller steps you aim to tackle within it.

You can then just use PRs to make those changes and reference back to that ticket.

That's probably what I would do, anyway.

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-17 10:06:36

*Thread Reply:* I think the only caveat to that is if there's anything that needs discussion before you make a start on it. Having discussions about multiple topics in the thread of a single issue can get confusing. If that's the case, multiple tickets would be better, unless that discussion could happen in the PR.

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-17 10:06:44

*Thread Reply:* I'm excited to see what you come up with!

2022-01-17 10:58:29

<p>This issue is to track and discuss pull requests that I'm working on to help improve the documentation of Cucumber, including resolving some inaccuracies where the markdown files haven't been updated to reflect the current behavior of the application.</p>

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/pull/31

<https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/pull/31|#31 Update dependency @cucumber/language-server to ^0.4.0>
<p><a href="https://renovatebot.com">WhiteSource Renovate</a></p> <p>This PR contains the following updates:</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Release Notes</strong> cucumber/language-server <strong><a href="https://togithub.com/cucumber/language-server/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#%E2%80%8B040---2022-01-19|&lt;code">https://togithub.com/cucumber/language-server/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#%E2%80%8B040---2022-01-19|<code</a>v0.4.0</code>&gt;</strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/cucumber/language-server/compare/v0.3.3...v0.4.0">Compare Source</a></p> <p><strong>Added</strong></p> <p>• Added settings (with reasonable defaults) so the client can specify where the source<br /> code is. The server uses this for auto complete and detecting defined steps.</p> <p><strong>Fixed</strong></p> <p>• Fixed auto complete by re-enabling the building of the index that backs it.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Configuration</strong></p> <p>📅 <strong>Schedule</strong>: At any time (no schedule defined).</p> <p>🚦 <strong>Automerge</strong>: Enabled.</p> <p>♻️ <strong>Rebasing</strong>: Whenever PR is behind base branch, or you tick the rebase/retry checkbox.</p> <p>🔕 <strong>Ignore</strong>: Close this PR and you won't be reminded about this update again.</p> <hr /> <p>☐ If you want to rebase/retry this PR, click this checkbox.</p> <hr /> <p>This PR has been generated by <a href="https://renovate.whitesourcesoftware.com">WhiteSource Renovate</a>. View repository job log <a href="https://app.renovatebot.com/dashboard#github/cucumber/monaco">here</a>.</p>

Aslak Hellesøy
2022-02-02 16:12:18

*Thread Reply:* @olleolleolle Related: • https://github.com/cucumber/language-server/issues/28 • https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/issues/38 • https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/issues/39

<https://github.com/cucumber/language-server/issues/28|#28 Move tree-sitter logic to language-service>
<p>The <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/monaco">@cucumber/monaco</a> module needs the tree-sitter functionality, but not the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-server">@cucumber/language-server</a> functionality. Since <code>@cucumber/monaco</code> depends on <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-service">@cucumber/language-service</a>, we should move the tree-sitter functionality there.</p> <p>It used to be in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-service">@cucumber/language-service</a>, but it was removed in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-service/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#0100---2021-11-08">0.10.0</a>. Let's undo that.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/language-server">cucumber/language-server</a>

olleolleolle
2022-02-02 23:01:21

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/pull/40

<https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/pull/40|#40 CI: Drop Node.js 12.x, and windows+Node.js 17.x>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>"Since this is a browser library we don't need to test it extensively on many OS/Node versions."</p> <p>Fixes <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/monaco/issues/39">#39</a>.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>This makes Windows build failures go away, by not testing on Windows.</p> <p>One goal here is to get to a consistent green build.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☐ My change needed additional tests ☐ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/monaco">cucumber/monaco</a>
👍 Aslak Hellesøy
olleolleolle
2022-02-04 02:00:57

I wonder if the https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js needs to support ancient Node.js versions. What is ancient, at this juncture?

cucumber/screenplay.js
Library to ease implementation of the Screenplay pattern with CucumberJS

David Goss
2022-02-04 02:28:24

*Thread Reply:* We generally go by their schedule and support any LTS versions plus the current, if that's helps - so right now it's 12, 14, 16 and 17 https://nodejs.org/en/about/releases/

Node.js
Releases | Node.js
Node.js® is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine.
Original URL: https://nodejs.org/en/about/releases/
Aslak Hellesøy
2022-02-04 08:21:03

*Thread Reply:* Screenplay is missing 17

2022-02-05 11:10:56

*Thread Reply:* Cool, I made a PR which adds 17, (Windows, Ubuntu, Windows).

olleolleolle
2022-02-05 11:13:28

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/71 It ran green

<https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/71|#71 CI: Add Node 17.x to matrix>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>This PR adds the Node 17.x build target, for Ubuntu, Windows and macOS.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>I asked in Slack, <a href="https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C612KCP1P/p1643968857727739">https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C612KCP1P/p1643968857727739</a> what are the supported versions of Node.js? ("Which versions are deemed ancient?")</p> <p>It was found that 17.x was not in the build matrix.</p> <p>Question: Should we quell 16.x's building on Windows+macOS, now that 17.x is the latest release? 16.x is the LTS, hmm. Perhaps 17.x shouldn't run on anything but Ubuntu? What are your thoughts about this?</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt - ensuring that we run on latest Node.js major release</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☐ My change needed additional tests ☐ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js">cucumber/screenplay.js</a>

olleolleolle
2022-02-05 12:00:18

*Thread Reply:* When I came to, I had read https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007

<https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1007|#1007 ESM support: soliciting feedback>
<p>Please use this ticket to provide feedback on our native ESM support. Your involvement is greatly appreciated to ensure the feature works on real-world projects.</p> <p><strong>Experimental warning</strong></p> <p><a href="https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#esm_experimental_loaders">Node's loader hooks</a> are <strong>EXPERIMENTAL</strong> and subject to change. ts-node's ESM support is as stable as it can be, but it relies on APIs which node can <em>and will</em> break in new versions of node.</p> <p>When node breaks their APIs, it breaks loaders using their APIs. You have been warned!</p> <p><strong>node's API change: v16.12.0, v17.0.0</strong></p> <p>Node made a breaking change in their ESM API in version 17, backported to 16.12.0. It may also be backported to 14 and 12.<br /> This is the change: <a href="https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/37468">nodejs/node#37468</a></p> <p>ts-node automatically supports both APIs, thanks to <a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/pull/1457">#1457</a>. This relies on hard-coded version number checks. If/when this is backported to node 14 and 12, we will publish a new version of ts-node with the appropriate version number checks. Be sure you are always using the latest version of ts-node to avoid problems.</p> <p><strong>Usage</strong> <strong>Requirements</strong></p> <p>• Set <code>"module": "ESNext"</code> or <code>"ES2015"</code> so that TypeScript emits import/export syntax. • Set <code>"type": "module"</code> in your <code>package.json</code>, which is required to tell node that .js files are ESM instead of CommonJS. To be compatible with editors, the compiler, and the TypeScript ecosystem, we cannot name our source files <code>.mts</code> nor <code>.mjs</code>. • Install ts-node locally, not globally. <code>npm install ts-node</code> or <code>yarn add ts-node</code> • Include file extensions in your <code>import</code> statements, or pass <code>--experimental-specifier-resolution=node</code> Idiomatic TypeScript should import <code>foo.ts</code> as <code>import 'foo.js';</code> TypeScript understands this. • The language service accepts configuration to include the file extension in automatically-written imports. In VSCode:<br /> <a href="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/376504/80899399-a3ae6d80-8cdd-11ea-85ea-b19151dad841.png">image</a></p> <p><strong>Invocation</strong></p> <pre><code>node --loader ts-node/esm ./my-script.ts # To force the use of a specific tsconfig.json, use the TS_NODE_PROJECT environment variable TS_NODE_PROJECT="path/to/tsconfig.json" node --loader ts-node/esm ./my-script.ts </code></pre> <p>You must invoke <code>node</code> directly because there is no way for us to enable our loader hook at runtime. Be aware this imposes some limitations on our implementation.</p> <p><strong>Configuration</strong></p> <p><code>tsconfig.json</code> <em>is</em> parsed.<br /> CLI flags are <em>not</em> parsed.<br /> Environment variables <em>are</em> parsed.</p> <p>tsconfig will be resolved relative to <code>process.cwd()</code> or to <code>TS_NODE_PROJECT</code>. Specify ts-node options in your tsconfig file. For details, see our <a href="https://typestrong.org/ts-node/docs/configuration#via-tsconfigjson-recommended">docs</a>.</p> <p>You can use <code>TS_NODE_PROJECT</code> to tell ts-node to use a specific tsconfig, and you can put all other ts-node options into this config file.</p> <p><strong>Versioning</strong></p> <p>As long as node's APIs are experimental, all changes to ESM support in ts-node, including breaking changes, will be released as minor or patch versions, <em>NOT</em> major versions. This conforms to semantic versioning's philosophy for version numbers lower than 1.0. Stable features will continue to be versioned as normal.</p> <hr /> <hr /> <hr /> <hr /> <p><em>Note: things below this line may be out-of-date or inaccurate. These notes were used during initial implementation, but have not been updated since</em></p> <p><strong>Pending development work</strong></p> <p>☐ Make resolution lookup use our fs caches ☐ Create esm-script.mjs to do --script-mode? • Can read <code>process.argv</code> for config resolution? ☑︎ Implement <code>require('ts-node').esmImport(module, 'import-path')</code> • use <a href="https://npm.im/tsimportlib">https://npm.im/tsimportlib</a> ☑︎ Throw error when CJS attempts to require ESM, matching node's behavior for .js • See below: "Changes to existing functionality" &gt; "require() hook"</p> <p><strong>The proposal</strong></p> <p>Below is the official proposal, explaining our implementation in detail.</p> <hr /> <p><em>I am asking node's modules team questions here: <a href="https://github.com/nodejs/modules/issues/351">nodejs/modules#351</a></em></p> <p>I was reading the threads about ESM support in ts-node, e.g. <a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/935">#935</a>.</p> <p>The @K-FOSS/TS-ESNode implementation is unfortunately incomplete; it does not attempt to typecheck. (it uses transpileModule)</p> <p>So I did some research. Below is a proposal for ESM support in <code>ts-node</code>, describing the required behavior in detail.</p> <p>This doesn't feel like an urgent feature to me, but I like having an official proposal we can work on.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Usage</strong></p> <pre><code>node --loader ts-node/esm ./entrypoint.ts </code></pre> <p>Cannot be invoked as <code>ts-node</code> because it requires node flags; hooks cannot be enabled at runtime. This is unavoidable.</p> <p>For simplicity, <code>--require ts-node/register</code> can be eliminated, because <code>ts-node/esm</code> automatically does that.</p> <p>Alternatively, we publish an experimental <code>ts-node-esm</code> entry-point which invokes a <code>node</code> subprocess.</p> <hr /> <p>Don't forget <code>allowJs</code>! Affects the treatment of <code>.js</code> files. (Not <code>.mjs</code> nor <code>.cjs</code> because the TS language service won't look at them)</p> <p><strong>ESM hooks</strong></p> <p>Must implement ESM hooks to resolve extensionless imports to .ts files, resolve .js to .ts, classify .ts(x) and .jsx files as CJS or MJS, and compile .ts(x) and .jsx files.</p> <p><strong><code>resolve()</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>Match additional file extensions: <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, <code>.jsx</code>.</p> <p>Resolve <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, and <code>.jsx</code> if the import specifier says <code>.js</code>. Obey preferTsExts when doing this.</p> <p>_</p> <p>[Good idea?] Always ask default resolver first. If it finds something, we should not interfere.</p> <p><code>--experimental-specifier-resolution=node</code> does <em>not</em> obey <code>require.extensions</code>, unfortunately, so we can't use that.</p> <p><strong><code>getFormat</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>If the resolved file is <code>.ts</code>, <code>.tsx</code>, or <code>.jsx</code>, behave as if extension was <code>.js</code>: use node's <code>package.json</code> discovery behavior to figure out if ESM or CJS.</p> <p>This can be accomplished by appending <code>.js</code> to the URL path and delegating to built-in <code>getFormat</code> hook.</p> <p><strong><code>transformSource</code> hook:</strong></p> <p>Same as today's code transformer. Relies on projects to be configured correctly for <code>import</code>/<code>export</code> emit.</p> <p><strong>Changes to existing functionality</strong> <strong><code>require()</code> hook</strong></p> <p>• Use same <code>getFormat</code> logic to determine if node will treat file as CJS or ESM. • NOTE node already detects and throws some errors on its own. But if <code>require.resolve</code> points to a <code>.ts</code> file, we need to make the determination. • If ESM, throw the same error as NodeJS ("cannot load ESM via require()") • copying logic from <a href="https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/38998d85384f85fd36fb478d20557d80de886949/lib/internal/modules/cjs/loader.js#L1184-L1197">node's source here</a></p> <p><strong><code>require()</code> code transform</strong></p> <p>• Must somehow allow <code>import()</code> calls. • Force consumers to use <code>require('ts-node').esmImport(module, 'import-path')</code>?</p> <p><strong><code>ts-node</code> bin entry-point</strong></p> <p><code>ts-node</code> CLI does <em>NOT</em> need to support <code>import()</code>ing ESM.</p> <p>WHY? Because ESM hooks are an experimental feature which <em>must</em> be enabled via node CLI flag.</p> <p>Thus we will be loaded via <code>--require</code>, and Node is responsible for loading the entry-point, either triggering our hook or our <code>require.extensions</code>.</p> <p><strong>Allow <code>import()</code> in CJS</strong></p> <p>If <code>"module": "commonjs"</code>, compiler transforms <code>import()</code> into <code>__importStar</code></p> <p>No way to change this without a custom transformer, which IMO is too much complexity at this time.</p> <p>Users should run their code as ESM.</p> <p>If they can't do that, we can recommend the following workaround:</p> <pre><code>// This is in a CommonJS file: const dynamicallyImportedEsmModule = await require('ts-node').importESM('./specifier-of-esm-module', module); </code></pre> <p><strong>Emit considerations</strong></p> <p><em>NOTE we have not implemented the following, although initially I thought we might. Instead, we assume tsconfig is configured for either ESM or CJS as needed</em></p> <p>We could intelligently emit both <code>"module": "esnext"</code> and <code>"module": "commonjs"</code> depending on the classification of a file.</p> <p>In <code>transpile-only</code> mode this is simple. Call <code>transpileModule</code> with diffe…</p>
Labels
enhancement, research

<a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node">TypeStrong/ts-node</a>
olleolleolle
2022-02-05 12:00:35

😆 Jo Laing, matt-SmartBear
Aurélien Reeves
2022-02-07 00:11:24

*Thread Reply:* Hi @olleolleolle

As you noticed, we already started working on the ESM thing.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/issues/7 https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/17

But we are facing some dificulties at the moment.

So, when converting modules into hybrid esm/cjs ones for the other cucumber modules using the esm loader from ts-node, we faced no specific issues.

But with cucumber/react, the loader does not work with the css/scss files.

Our last progress in the PR #17 was that we have extended the ts-node esm loader to be able to import css/scss. But now, it seems it has lost the ability to interpret JSX/TSX.

Well, welcome to Wonderland @olleolleolle! 🎉

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/issues/7|#7 Make ESM module>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react">cucumber/cucumber-react</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/17|#17 Convert into a hybrid cjs/esm package>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react">cucumber/cucumber-react</a>
olleolleolle
2022-02-08 10:13:36

This is now GREEN (!) https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/52

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/52|#52 chore(deps): update dependency ts-node to v10.5.0>
<p><a href="https://renovatebot.com">WhiteSource Renovate</a></p> <p>This PR contains the following updates:</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Release Notes</strong> TypeStrong/ts-node <strong><a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/releases/v10.5.0"><code>v10.5.0</code></a></strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/compare/v10.4.0...v10.5.0">Compare Source</a></p> <p>Questions about this release? Ask in the official discussion thread: <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1634">#​1634</a></p> <p><strong>Added</strong></p> <p>• Eliminate "Emit Skipped" errors (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/693">#​693</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1345">#​1345</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1629">#​1629</a>) • Avoids all "Emit Skipped" errors by performing a fallback <code>transpileOnly</code>-style transformation. • Does not affect typechecking. Type errors are still detected and thrown. • Fallback has the same limitations as <code>isolatedModules</code>. This will only affect rare cases such as using <code>const enums</code> with <code>preserveConstEnums</code> disabled. • Fixes <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/693">#​693</a> • Graduate swc transpiler out of experimental; add <code>swc: true</code> convenience option (<a href="https://typestrong.org/ts-node/docs/transpilers">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1487">#​1487</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1536">#​1536</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1613">#​1613</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1627">#​1627</a>) • <code>"swc": true</code> or <code>--swc</code> will use swc for faster execution • This feature is no longer marked "experimental." Thank you to everyone who filed bugs! • swc transpiler attempts to load <code>@swc/core</code> or <code>@swc/wasm</code> dependencies from your project before falling-back to global installations (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1613">#​1613</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1627">#​1627</a>) • global fallback only occurs when using a global installation of ts-node • Add support for TypeScript's <code>traceResolution</code> output (<a href="https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#traceResolution">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1128">#​1128</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1491">#​1491</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/TheUnlocked">@​TheUnlocked</a> • Support import assertions in ESM loader (<a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v17.x/docs/api/esm.html#import-assertions">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1557">#​1557</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1558">#​1558</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1559">#​1559</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1573">#​1573</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/Pokute">@​Pokute</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/geigerzaehler">@​geigerzaehler</a> • Allows importing JSON files from ESM with the requisite flag (<a href="https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v17.x/docs/api/esm.html#json-modules">docs</a>) • <code>ts-node -vvv</code> also logs absolute paths to <code>ts-node</code> and <code>typescript</code>, to make it more obvious when you're accidentally using globally-installed versions (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1323">#​1323</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1620">#​1620</a>) • Add swc target "es2022" (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1535">#​1535</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1540">#​1540</a>) • When you have target es2022 in tsconfig, will use swc's es2022 target</p> <p><strong>Changed</strong></p> <p>• Initialize TypeScript compiler before starting REPL prompt (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1498">#​1498</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/TheUnlocked">@​TheUnlocked</a> • Improves responsiveness for first line of REPL input • Use <code>v8-compile-cache-lib</code> to load typescript • improves startup time (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1339">#​1339</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1603">#​1603</a>) • Support both <code>--camelCase</code> and <code>--hyphen-case</code> for all CLI flags; update documentation to use <code>--camelCase</code> (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1598">#​1598</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1599">#​1599</a>) • Not a breaking change; CLI continues to accept both forms • Make <code>TSError</code> <code>diagnosticText</code> property non-enumerable to prevent it from being logged below the stack (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1632">#​1632</a>)</p> <p><strong>Fixed</strong></p> <p>• Fix <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1538">#​1538</a>: REPL inputs fail to transpile via swc (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1538">#​1538</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1541">#​1541</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1602">#​1602</a>) • Fix <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1478">#​1478</a>: REPL erroneously logged <code>undefined</code> for all inputs after the first when using swc transpiler (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1478">#​1478</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1580">#​1580</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1602">#​1602</a>) • Fix <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1389">#​1389</a>: In <code>--showConfig</code> output, emit accurate <code>moduleTypes</code> paths resolved relative to the <code>tsconfig.json</code> which declared them (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1389">#​1389</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1619">#​1619</a>) • Fix: Remove indentation from <code>ts-node --help</code> output (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1597">#​1597</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1600">#​1600</a>) • Fix <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1425">#​1425</a>: Merged definitions correctly into <code>tsconfig.schemastore-schema.json</code> (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1425">#​1425</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1618">#​1618</a>) • Fix: Allow disabling <code>"use strict"</code> emit in SWC transpiler (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1531">#​1531</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1537">#​1537</a>) • Fix: Add missing <code>ERR_UNKNOWN_FILE_EXTENSION</code> constructor; was throwing <code>ERR_UNKNOWN_FILE_EXTENSION is not a constructor</code> (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1562">#​1562</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/bluelovers">@​bluelovers</a> • Fix <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1565">#​1565</a>: entrypoint resolution failed on node v12.0.x and v12.1.x (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1565">#​1565</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1566">#​1566</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/davidmurdoch">@​davidmurdoch</a></p> <p><strong>Docs</strong></p> <p>• Explain <code>env -S</code> flag for shebangs (<a href="https://typestrong.org/ts-node/docs/usage#shebang">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1448">#​1448</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1545">#​1545</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/sheeit">@​sheeit</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/chee">@​chee</a> • Suggest <code>skipIgnore</code> when you want to compile files in node_modules (<a href="https://typestrong.org/ts-node/docs/how-it-works">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1553">#​1553</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/webstrand">@​webstrand</a> • Fix typo in <code>moduleTypes</code> on options page (<a href="https://typestrong.org/ts-node/docs/options">docs</a>) (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1630">#​1630</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1633">#​1633</a>)</p> <p><strong>Misc</strong></p> <p>• Adds experimental <code>experimentalResolverFeatures</code> option, but it does not do anything yet (<a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1514">#​1514</a>, <a href="https://togithub.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/1614">#​1614</a>)</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/milestone/4">https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/milestone/4</a></p> <hr /> <p><strong>Configuration</strong></p> <p>📅 <strong>Schedule</strong>: At any time (no schedule defined).</p> <p>🚦 <strong>Automerge</strong>: Enabled.</p> <p>♻️ <strong>Rebasing</strong>: Whenever PR is behind base branch, or you tick the rebase/retry checkbox.</p> <p>🔕 <strong>Ignore</strong>: Close this PR and you won't be reminded about this update again.</p> <hr /> <p>☐ If you want to rebase/retry this PR, click this checkbox.</p> <hr /> <p>This PR has been generated by <a href="https://renovate.whitesourcesoftware.com">WhiteSource Renovate</a>. 🤖 dependencies
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react">cucumber/cucumber-react</a>
Jonas Amundsen
2022-02-15 09:14:59

From cucumber-js' changelog:

> Clarify that the JSON formatter will not be removed any time soon Where is this clarified? 🙂

David Goss
2022-02-15 13:23:25

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/docs/formatters.md#json

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/docs/formatters.md | formatters.md>
<p><strong>Formatters</strong></p> <p>In cucumber-js, Formatters ingest data about your test run in real time and then output content, either to the console or a file, in a useful format. (Some frameworks refer to this kind of thing as "reporters".)</p> <p>cucumber-js provides many built-in Formatters, plus building blocks with which you can &lt;./custom_formatters.md|write your own&gt;.</p> <p>You can specify one or more formats via the <code>--format &amp;lt;TYPE[:PATH]&amp;gt;</code> CLI option, where <code>TYPE</code> is one of:</p> <p>• The name of one of the built-in formatters (below) e.g. <code>progress</code> • A module/package name e.g. <code>@cucumber/pretty-formatter</code> • A relative path to a local formatter implementation e.g. <code>./my-customer-formatter.js</code></p> <p>If <code>PATH</code> is supplied, the formatter prints to the given file, otherwise it prints to <code>stdout</code>.</p> <p>Some notes on specifying Formatters:</p> <p>• If multiple formatters are specified with the same output, only the last is used. • If no formatter for <code>stdout</code> is specified, we default to the <code>progress</code> formatter.</p> <p><strong>Options</strong></p> <p>Many formatters, including the built-in ones, support some configurability via options. You can provide this data as a JSON literal via the <code>--format-options</code> CLI option, like this:</p> <pre><code>$ cucumber-js --format-options '{"someOption":true}' </code></pre> <p>This option is repeatable, so you can use it multiple times and the objects will be merged with the later ones taking precedence.</p> <p>Some options offered by built-in formatters:</p> <p>• <code>colorsEnabled</code> - if set to <code>false</code>, colors in terminal output are disabled.</p> <p><strong>Built-in formatters</strong> <strong><code>summary</code></strong></p> <p>The Summary Formatter outputs a summary of the test run's results.</p> <p>If everything passed, this will be short and sweet:</p> <p>&lt;./images/summary<em>green.gif|./images/summary</em>green.gif&gt;</p> <p>If there were issues, you'll see useful details including:</p> <p>• Failed hooks or steps including error messages and stack traces • Locations of any pending steps • &lt;./snippets.md|Snippets&gt; to implement any undefined steps</p> <p><strong><code>progress</code></strong></p> <p>The Progress Formatter has the same output as the Summary Formatter at the end of the test run, but also provides concise real-time feedback each time a step or hook completes:</p> <p>&lt;./images/progress.gif|./images/progress.gif&gt;</p> <p><strong><code>progress-bar</code></strong></p> <p>Similar to the Progress Formatter, but provides a real-time updating progress bar based on the total number of steps to be executed in the test run:</p> <p>&lt;./images/progress<em>bar</em>green.gif|./images/progress<em>bar</em>green.gif&gt;</p> <p><em>Note: the Progress Bar Formatter will only work with a TTY terminal (and not, for example, a file stream).</em></p> <p><strong><code>html</code></strong></p> <p>The HTML Formatter produces a rich interactive report bundled as a standalone HTML page:</p> <p>&lt;./images/html<em>formatter.png|./images/html</em>formatter.png&gt;</p> <p>You can:</p> <p>• See detailed results including error messages and stack traces • See attachments rendered in-place • Filter to specific statuses • Search by keywords or tag expressions</p> <p><strong><code>message</code></strong></p> <p>Outputs all the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/tree/main/messages">Cucumber Messages</a> for the test run as newline-delimited JSON, which can then be consumed by other tools.</p> <p><strong><code>json</code></strong></p> <p>Outputs details of the test run in the legacy JSON format.</p> <p><em>Note: this formatter is in maintenance mode and won't have new features added to it. Where you need a structured data representation of your test run, it's best to use the <code>message</code> formatter. Tools that rely on this formatter will continue to work, but are encouraged to migrate to consume the <code>message</code> output instead.</em></p> <p><strong><code>snippets</code></strong></p> <p>The Snippets Formatter doesn't output anything regarding the test run; it just prints &lt;./snippets.md|Snippets to implement any undefined steps&gt;. This is useful when you want to quickly zero in on the steps you have to implement and grab the snippet code for them in one go.</p> <p><strong><code>usage</code></strong></p> <p>The Usage Formatter lists your step definitions and tells you about usages in your scenarios, including the duration of each usage, and any unused steps. Here's an example of the output:</p> <pre><code>┌───────────────────────────────────────┬──────────┬─────────────────────────────────┐ │ Pattern / Text │ Duration │ Location │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ an empty todo list │ 760.33ms │ support/steps/steps.ts:6 │ │ an empty todo list │ 820ms │ features/empty.feature:4 │ │ an empty todo list │ 761ms │ features/adding-todos.feature:4 │ │ an empty todo list │ 700ms │ features/empty.feature:4 │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ I add the todo {string} │ 432.00ms │ support/steps/steps.ts:10 │ │ I add the todo "buy some cheese" │ 432ms │ features/adding-todos.feature:5 │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ my cursor is ready to create a todo │ 53.00ms │ support/steps/steps.ts:27 │ │ my cursor is ready to create a todo │ 101ms │ features/empty.feature:10 │ │ my cursor is ready to create a todo │ 5ms │ features/adding-todos.feature:8 │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ no todos are listed │ 46.00ms │ support/steps/steps.ts:15 │ │ no todos are listed │ 46ms │ features/empty.feature:7 │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ the todos are: │ 31.00ms │ support/steps/steps.ts:21 │ │ the todos are: │ 31ms │ features/adding-todos.feature:6 │ ├───────────────────────────────────────┼──────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ I remove the todo {string} │ UNUSED │ support/steps/steps.ts:33 │ └───────────────────────────────────────┴──────────┴─────────────────────────────────┘ </code></pre> <p><strong><code>usage-json</code></strong></p> <p>Does what the Usage Formatter does, but outputs JSON, which can be output to a file and then consumed by other tools.</p> <p><strong>Other officially-supported formatters</strong></p> <p>• <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/@cucumber/pretty-formatter">@cucumber/pretty-formatter</a> - prints the feature with inline results, colours and custom themes.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
David Goss
2022-02-15 13:24:53

*Thread Reply:* For a while it emitted a deprecation warning in the console, which it now doesn't. Essentially we backtracked on removing it after seeing the impact that would have had.

Jonas Amundsen
2022-02-16 05:39:44

*Thread Reply:* Alright! I think that was wise, although I understand the desire to not maintain it

Jonas Amundsen
2022-02-20 03:24:46

I would love for pretty() of @cucumber/gherkin-utils to retain comments and be able to use it in our (currently internal) vscode plugin for cypress-cucumber integration. Is someone currently thinking about this? If not, then I might be able to take a stab at it sometime.

Aslak Hellesøy
2022-02-21 11:46:18

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Jonas Amundsen - there is a draft PR here: https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1738

It's stalled (nobody has worked on it in a while), so if you want to keep working on it - that would be great!

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1738|#1738 Walk/pretty print comments>
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>• Walk comments in <code>walkGherkinDocument</code> • Pretty print comments in <code>pretty</code></p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>Keep a stack of comments and pop/walk comments until the current AST node.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>I've just added a couple of unit tests - we need more thorough tests for this:</p> <p>☐ Add comments everywhere in <code>walkGherkinDocumentTest</code> ☐ Add more edge case tests for <code>pretty</code></p> <p><strong>Screenshots (if appropriate):</strong> <strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue). ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ The change has been ported to Java. ☐ The change has been ported to Ruby. ☑︎ The change has been ported to JavaScript. ☐ The change has been ported to Go. ☐ The change has been ported to .NET. ☐ I've added tests for my code. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ I have updated the CHANGELOG accordingly.</p>

Jonas Amundsen
2022-02-22 01:55:05

*Thread Reply:* One thing I like about other "prettifiers" is the ability to truncate duplicate whitespace, but otherwise retain it. With that I mean that both the following gherkin documents would be "valid" and "prettified" to itself:

Feature: foo Scenario: bar Given some step ```Feature: foo

Scenario: bar Given some step```

Jonas Amundsen
2022-02-22 01:56:16

*Thread Reply:* For a prettifier I invoke through my IDE, this seems imperative

2022-07-04 09:41:35

*Thread Reply:* I was looking at the AST in connection with this. There's two things so far I've noticed missing, that I need in order to get perfect prettifying as described above.

• Location of the dialect commet, EG. # language: no (it's not added to ast's comments section) • Location attribute of description blocks (they only exists as string of EG. scenarios) Would you be open to extending messages to include location in descriptions, as well as appending dialect-comments to comments?

2022-07-04 10:26:01

👋 Hello, JSers.

I attempted to fix a TS lint warning (which does fail the build in a certain PR) - could you check this change for me? https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/78

<https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/78|#78 Fix TS7030 by returning something (null)>
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>I have added a return value to a callback which seemed to need one, according to TS7030.</p> <p>I picked the return value <code>null</code> to make it a... simple value.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p>This issue came up when running "npm run build" for the PR <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/74">#74</a> about updateing @types/node to v16.11.25.</p> <p>Here is some output:</p> <p>&gt; ➜ screenplay.js git:(renovate/node-16.x) npm run build &gt; &gt; &gt; @cucumber/screenplay@5.1.0 build<br /> &gt; &gt; tsc --build tsconfig.json &gt; &gt; features/src/server.ts:20:24 - error TS7030: Not all code paths return a value. &gt; &gt; 20 exp.get('/messages', (req, res) =&gt; {<br /> &gt; ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ &gt; &gt; Found 1 error.</p> <p>With this, I can run the <code>npm run build</code> in the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js/pull/74">#74</a> Pull Request.</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• 🐛 Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes a defect)</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☐ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☐ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ Users should know about my change ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/screenplay.js">cucumber/screenplay.js</a>
✅ olleolleolle
matt-SmartBear
2022-02-22 12:33:36

*Thread Reply:* I'm really puzzled by this one.

Those express handlers appear to me to be typed with a return type of void which should mean that they don't need to return anything. It almost feels like a bug in that point release of @node/types and I've been trying to look for a changelog or something but I can't fathom it out.

2022-02-22 23:59:58

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
🙌 Aurélien Reeves
Aurélien Reeves
2022-03-03 07:20:58

As discussed during the meeting, for gherkin-streams (and messages-streams, we will have the exact same issue), I suggest to make gherkin and messages "peer" dependencies rather than "regular" dependencies for "gherkin-streams" and "messages-streams". Peer dependencies needs great attention, but I guess it makes good sense in the context of gherkin-streams and messages-streams. Any objection or though about that?

👍 David Goss
David Goss
2022-03-03 07:24:12

*Thread Reply:* I think it makes sense. In both cases the -streams package is using a very specific and stable API so I don’t think we should need to worry about a specific version of the related core library except majors.

This might lessen the cascade of releases needed when messages changes to avoid having multiple versions of messages in the dependency tree.

David Goss
2022-03-03 07:24:54

*Thread Reply:* Other libs we could potentially do this with: query, gherkin-utils

matt-SmartBear
2022-03-29 11:10:39

@David Goss re. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1955/files/5ca8c5ef8051410eaf46ccc6c6a7d644234fadd6#r832888424

I was wracking my brains at the time to find a name that I knew was relevant here, and it's popped into my head this morning: "test plan".

From: https://junit.org/junit5/docs/5.0.3/api/org/junit/platform/launcher/TestPlan.html

Dunno if it's still relevant or useful but I needed to share the insight now it's come to me!

David Goss
2022-03-30 01:38:35

*Thread Reply:* Yeah I had a similar thought. IMO runConfiguration isn’t quite a test plan, it’s more like coordinates that can be used to formulate one. But there is the loadSources method that does return something called a “plan” which is basically the pickles that will be run and in what order.

David Goss
2022-03-30 01:38:49

*Thread Reply:* (thanks for circling back!)

Aslak Hellesøy

👋 Kacper Marcisz
David Goss
2022-04-04 14:09:32

*Thread Reply:* Once this is in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1985 I’m happy to ship a 8.0.0

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1985|#1985 fix: try require first for custom formatters so transpiled ones work>
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>Tweak the loading of custom formatters and snippet syntaxes so we try <code>require()</code> first and then try <code>import()</code> if it turns out the target file is a module (ESM).</p> <p>This mirrors how we are also now loading the configuration file.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p><a href="https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C6QJ6N695/p1649071066867509">https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C6QJ6N695/p1649071066867509</a></p> <p>An edge case arguably, but some users in the wild have formatters in their project written in TypeScript (or something else that transpiles) and take advantage of the fact that <code>--require-module</code> means their transpiler has registered by the time the formatter is loaded.</p> <p>This is quite cool and something we should avoid breaking if possible. We broke it with earlier RCs because we switched to exclusively using <code>import()</code> to load custom formatters, which doesn't yet account for just-in-time transpiled code.</p> <p>In 1 or 2 major releases (when loader hooks are a solved problem) we'll ditch the <code>require()</code> bit and just use <code>import()</code> but for now this works reliably and is well covered by tests.</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• 🐛 Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes a defect)</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☑︎ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☑︎ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ Users should know about my change ☑︎ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p> <hr /> <p><em>This text was originally generated from a <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/about-issue-and-pull-request-templates">template</a>, then edited by hand. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/edit/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md">You can modify the template here.</a></em></p>
Comments

Milestone
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/milestone/14">ESM</a>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
Kacper Marcisz
2022-04-04 08:54:58

@Kacper Marcisz has joined the channel

David Goss
2022-04-08 06:23:50

⁉️ any objections here before I push on with finishing this? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/131

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react/pull/131|#131 chore: update project structure and tooling>
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>• Tests are now colocated with sources, not in a <code>test</code> dir • Tests are named <code>**.spec.tsx</code> • Tests are run with Jest, using jest-dom for assertions and testing library for rendering</p> <p><strong>Note:</strong> This is part done for illustrative purposes, the majority is still running with Mocha.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p>Make this project more in keeping with React ecosystem conventions and thus more approachable for would-be external contributors. Also better DX generally with Jest (with React anyway).</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• 🏦 Refactoring/debt/DX (improvement to code design, tooling, documentation etc. without changing behaviour)</p> <p><strong>♻️ Anything particular you want feedback on?</strong></p> <p>Any major objections? If not I'll carry on refactoring.</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☐ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☐ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ Users should know about my change ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p> <hr /> <p><em>This text was originally generated from a <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/about-issue-and-pull-request-templates">template</a>, then edited by hand. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/edit/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md">You can modify the template here.</a></em></p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-react">cucumber/cucumber-react</a>
Aurélien Reeves
2022-04-13 00:21:50

We have some dependencies that are declared several times but actually are required only once due to how our own dependencies could resolve those.

For example, react: it is declared in both react-components, and the html-formatter. It works ok, but when there is an update, we have to take care to update all react in all dependent packages properly and in cascade.

Could we declare react a dependency in react-components, and then make it a peer dependency in dependent modules like the html-formatter? That way, when we update it one time in react-components, it is spread across other modules automatically when updating react-components in those?

David Goss
2022-04-13 00:44:28

*Thread Reply:* in this specific case we shouldn’t make react a dependency of @cucumber/react-components because that’d lock consuming apps to that specific version of React. html-formatter is the right place to depend on react because that’s the “app” in this case.

David Goss
2022-04-13 00:44:51

*Thread Reply:* i think in a more general sense we could lean on peer dependencies more for the @cucumber/** dependencies though, as we’ve started doing a bit already

Aurélien Reeves
2022-04-13 01:09:59

*Thread Reply:* 👍 thanks

Is this stand-alone formatter about to go away?

2022-06-01 08:57:58

👍 Aslak Hellesøy
David Goss
2022-06-01 09:01:07

(more specifically the goal for cucumber-js is to decouple from node, reduce dependencies and possibly modularise, such that it could be used on any js runtime including browsers again)

💯 matt-SmartBear
David Goss
2022-06-05 05:29:37

Thoughts welcome on https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/discussions/2059 - how I imagine we’ll fully transition to ESM in cucumber-js

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/discussions/2059|#2059 transition to ESM>
<p><strong>Background</strong></p> <p>The Node.js ecosystem is gradually moving from CommonJS (<code>require</code>, <code>module.exports</code> etc) to ESM (<code>import</code>, <code>export</code> etc).</p> <p>CommonJS code can be consumed by ESM code, but ESM code cannot be consumed by CommonJS code (because ESM is async and CommonJS is sync). This means that once a package switches to ESM, your project must be ESM to use it. As more open source projects switch, life will get harder for the remaining projects as they'll be unable to upgrade dependencies or add new dependencies that have switched. Switching to ESM also unlocks nice things like top-level await.</p> <p>As of 8.0.0, we added <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/v8.2.2/docs/esm.md">opt-in support for user code written in ES Modules</a>, and made Cucumber a hybrid package - meaning it's delivered in CommonJS format but has an ESM entry point. This involved a few compromises and leaves us in a transitional state.</p> <p><strong>Plan</strong></p> <p>Here's the (draft, for now) plan of how we eventually make the full switch to ESM:</p> <p><strong>Phase 0 - where we are now</strong></p> <p>• Cucumber is a hybrid module • The <code>--require</code> option loads code with <code>require()</code> (only works for CommonJS) • Transpilation is done via the <code>--require-module</code> option • The <code>--import</code> option loads code with <code>await import()</code> (works for both ESM and CommonJS) • Transpilation is done externally via Node.js <code>--loader</code> option (there's no mechanism to register loaders in-process) • The default behaviour (if neither of the above specified) uses <code>require()</code> • Custom formatters/snippets and configuration files are loaded with <code>require()</code>, with a fallback to retry with <code>await import()</code> • Deep requires (e.g. <code>require('@cucumber/cucumber/lib/models/test_case_hook_definition')</code>) still work <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/1902#issuecomment-1025976949">in a limited way</a></p> <p><strong>Phase 1: 9.0.0 - Q3/Q4 2022</strong></p> <p>• Cucumber is still a hybrid module • The <code>--require</code> and <code>--import</code> options still work as before • The default behaviour (if neither of the above specified) uses <code>await import()</code> • Custom formatters/snippets and configuration files are only loaded with <code>await import()</code> • Deep requires are gone (side note: this is good, we have control of what users are calling and can more confidently refactor internals) • Documentation and examples emphasise ESM syntax • <code>--require</code> and <code>--require-module</code> are deprecated, users are encouraged to switch to use <code>import()</code> and report any difficulties</p> <p><strong>Phase 2: a future major release</strong></p> <p>• Cucumber is an ESM module • <code>--require</code> and <code>--require-module</code> are gone, code is only loaded with <code>await import()</code></p> <p><strong>Stray thoughts</strong></p> <p>The time between phases 1 and 2 could be short or long; we can stay in a hybrid form for a while and take cues from the wider ecosystem. One milestone will be when <a href="https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#loaders">ESM loaders</a> become properly stable.</p> <p>Cucumber could be quicker to do this than other test runners, because the footprint of what's affected by <code>require</code> vs <code>import</code> is relatively small, unlike some to other tools that have e.g. module-level mocking built around <code>require</code>.</p>
Category
Announcements
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>

Michael Morris
2022-08-04 10:50:14

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2105

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2105|#2105 Throw a more detailed error message on require of ESM modules>
<p><strong>🤔 What's the problem you've observed?</strong></p> <p>I was stumped for about a full day by using the require directive in my configuration when I should have been using the import directive. Let's try to make the error message that the user sees more effective in pointing the user in the correct direction.</p> <p><strong>✨ Do you have a proposal for making it better?</strong></p> <p>Current error message</p> <pre><code>Error [ERR_REQUIRE_ESM]: require() of ES Module &amp;lt;step&amp;gt; from &amp;lt;project-root&amp;gt;\node_modules\@cucumber\cucumber\lib\api\support.js not supported. index.js is treated as an ES module file as it is a .js file whose nearest parent package.json contains "type": "module" which declares all .js files in that package scope as ES modules. Instead rename index.js to end in .cjs, change the requiring code to use dynamic import() which is available in all CommonJS modules, or change "type": "module" to "type": "commonjs" in C:\Users\tendo\Projects\ucx\mfa\tests\cucumber-screenplay\package.json to treat all .js files as CommonJS (using .mjs for all ES modules instead). </code></pre> <p>If we can catch that error we can throw this in it's place.</p> <pre><code>Error [ERR_REQUIRE_ESM]: require() of ES Module encountered. Use the import configuration directive instead of require. Example: cucumber-js --import steps.js </code></pre> <p>Maybe even go so far as to point out the exact code change needed?</p>

Adventurekateer
2022-10-07 16:18:36

@Adventurekateer has joined the channel

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-13 19:31:45

@David Goss I've been involved with a "hackathon" project at SmartBear today building a prototype Electron GUI on top of CucumberJS. We used the new API which was fantastic, and pretty easy to get working. A few observations / thoughts follow as separate messages in case you want to discuss them individually.

👍 David Goss
matt-SmartBear
2022-10-13 19:34:05

Initially we were confused that when we ran the simple example from https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/main/docs/javascript_api.md#simple-example and when we hit the "run test" button a second time, the step definitions were undefined.

I didn't really get my head around it, but it seems like we need to "pre-load" the steps defs using loadSupport and then re-use that each time we call runCucumber. Unless I misunderstood something.

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:42:38

*Thread Reply:* Yeah this is because Node.js caches modules that are imported or required, so if they’re loaded again in the same process they’ll be in the cache and won’t be executed again.

runCucumber does give you the support code library in its return object to reuse for future calls but it’s probably clearer to do loadSupport once upfront (that idea came from Nico building Stryker which had the same need).

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:47:23

*Thread Reply:* We could perhaps offer a “force” option to clear the cache for the files were going to load. That can be done for require but I’m not sure about ES imports yet.

David Goss
2022-10-15 05:04:07

*Thread Reply:* Mocha had the same thing https://github.com/nodejs/modules/issues/307#issuecomment-558462605. I’ll dig into this more soon.

<https://github.com/nodejs/modules/issues/307#issuecomment-558462605|Comment on #307 Invalidate cache when using import>
<p>FYI, I'm implementing ESM support in Mocha (<a href="https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/pull/4038">mochajs/mocha#4038</a>), and cannot currently implement "watch mode", whereby Mocha watches the test files, and reruns them when they change. So "watch mode" in Mocha, in the first iteration, will probably not support ESM, which is a bummer.</p> <p>While we <em>could</em> use cache busting query parameters, that would mean that we are always increasing memory usage, and old and never-to-be-used versions of the file will continue staying in memory due to the cache holding on to them.</p> <p>And I'm not sure a loader would help here, as the loader also has no access to the cache.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/nodejs/modules">nodejs/modules</a>
David Goss
2022-10-16 16:17:08

*Thread Reply:* (We kind of have to solve this properly to enable a rerun-when-files-change pattern which I’m guessing you’ll want for this.)

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-17 08:28:46

*Thread Reply:* I figured it was something like that, I remember similar issues with Ruby.

If you had two different support objects loaded (with two different sets of step definitions in them) you could switch between them, right? You just can re-load steps you've already loaded?

David Goss
2022-10-17 09:07:57

*Thread Reply:* Yes exactly.

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-13 19:34:31

The complex example is referring to a runnable that isn't defined anywhere in the example.

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:50:29

*Thread Reply:* Doh! I’ll fix it.

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:56:33

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/commit/7f436448a1eb13378b834e5cb76fe21721f994ef

2022-10-13 19:36:15

the onMessage callback caused much excitement and delight in the team! It occurred to me we could present it as an EventEmitter with on("testCaseStarted") events etc. which might be more idiomatic JavaScript.

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:43:15

*Thread Reply:* Glad it was useful!

*Thread Reply:* You mean the consumer passes an EventEmitter in?

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-17 08:31:54

*Thread Reply:* Either that, or the runCucumber call returns a more sophisticated object than a promise, that is an EventEmitter (and maybe includes an abort() interface too?)

matt-SmartBear

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:44:54

*Thread Reply:* Yeah I agree. It was kind of a pipe dream to generate docs from the code but they aren’t good enough. I’m going to replace them with more handwritten but useful docs.

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-17 08:33:50

*Thread Reply:* Is there not somewhere you can add more explanation around the generated docs? I think it's great that you know they're accurate, they just need more editorial around them.

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-13 21:13:39

It would be useful to be able to stop (or even pause) the test run from the client code. Is there a way to do that currently? If not, could we think about adding one?

David Goss
2022-10-15 04:49:51

*Thread Reply:* Not possible currently but yeah I can see the need for a programmatic stop. We could do a similar pattern to AbortController for fetch requests https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController

developer.mozilla.org
AbortController - Web APIs | MDN
The AbortController interface represents a controller object that allows you to abort one or more Web requests as and when desired.
Original URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController
David Goss
2022-10-15 04:50:14

*Thread Reply:* Pause maybe trickier. What’s the use case there out of interest?

matt-SmartBear
2022-10-17 08:33:10

*Thread Reply:* > Pause maybe trickier. What’s the use case there out of interest? Literally just the idea of a pause button on the GUI; maybe if a user had a really long scenario and they wanted to put a breakpoint on to see what's going on at a particular step to debug it.

Michael Morris
2023-01-06 10:10:15

*Thread Reply:* I was able to put a pause feature into my tests from userland by setting the timeout to -1 and then awating the input buffer.

Michael Morris
2023-01-06 10:13:02

*Thread Reply:* Relevant code: ```import After from "@cucumber/cucumber"; import readline from "readline";

async function waitforPrompt(prompt) { const rl = readline.createInterface({ input: process.stdin, output: process.stdout, });

return new Promise((resolve) =&gt; {
  rl.question(prompt, () =&gt; {
    rl.close();
    resolve();
  });
});

}

After({ timeout: -1 }, async function (scenario) { await waitforPrompt(Feature: ${scenario.gherkinDocument.feature.name}\nScenario: ${scenario.pickle.name}\nComplete. Press Enter to Continue.); await this.tearDown(); });```

matt-SmartBear
2023-01-06 10:48:21

*Thread Reply:* ha ha nice

2023-01-06 11:00:37

*Thread Reply:* This one looks reasonably simple to implement - https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2159

#2159 Reporters could create sub-directory automatically instead of failing
<p><strong>🤔 What's the problem you're trying to solve?</strong></p> <p><code>Cucumber</code> is unable to create report(s) if a sub-directory structure is specified and the same it's not present; e.g.: <code>html:reports/cucumber-report.html</code> — if <code>${CWD}/reports/</code> does not exist, the execution fails.</p> <p><strong>✨ What's your proposed solution?</strong></p> <p><code>Cucumber</code> should be able to create that path, something similar to <code>mkdir --parents ./reports/</code>.</p> <p><strong>⛏️ Have you considered any alternatives or workarounds?</strong></p> <p>Currently I'm using <code>mkdirp</code> module to create this path beforehand, but that requires some "orchestration" between <code>npm</code> scripts.</p> <hr /> <p><em>This text was originally generated from a <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/about-issue-and-pull-request-templates">template</a>, then edited by hand. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/edit/main/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/feature_request.md">You can modify the template here.</a></em></p>

#2218 Node 19 fails World Parameter invalid JSON test
<p>I checked out main, ran the test suite and got an error on one test:</p> <pre><code>1) Scenario: Invalid JSON # features\world_parameters.feature:15 √ Before # features\support\hooks.ts:14 √ Before # features\support\hooks.ts:18 √ Given a file named "features/passing_steps.feature" with: # features\step_definitions\file_steps.ts:11 """ Feature: a feature Scenario: a scenario Given the world parameters are correct """ √ When I run cucumber-js with `--world-parameters '{"a":}'` # features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:22 √ Then it fails # features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:81 × And the error output contains the text: # features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:141 """ --world-parameters passed invalid JSON: Unexpected token } """ AssertionError: expected 'This Node.js version (v19.4.0) has no…' to include '--world-parameters passed invalid JSO…' at World.&lt;anonymous&gt; (C:\Users\tendo\Projects\gitHub\cucumber_js\features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:146:29) - And the error output contains the text: # features\step_definitions\cli_steps.ts:141 """ {"a":} """ √ After # features\support\hooks.ts:55 </code></pre> <p><strong>Likely there's been a change in the error string in 19 and this will need to be detected and compensated for in the verification process.</strong></p> <p><em>This text was originally generated from a <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/about-issue-and-pull-request-templates">template</a>, then edited by hand. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/edit/main/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report.md">You can modify the template here.</a></em></p>

Ange
2023-02-26 18:20:16

@Ange has joined the channel

Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 09:00:01

In JsonFormatter, when populating the embeddings property, the attachments contentEncoding isn't taken into account, so the JSON reports may or may not contain base64 encoded data or identities. I'm wondering how to best solve this - should contentEncoding be propagated or perhaps that which isn't base64-encoded already, be encoded?

Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 09:00:37

(I'm talking about src/formatter/json_formatter.ts in cucumber-js here)

Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 09:02:22

I know that the standalone Go utility, will base64-encode that which isn't already

mpkorstanje
2023-03-19 10:41:42

*Thread Reply:* I don't quite get it. I would expect the bytes going in to always be encoded. Even if they're already encoded. Otherwise it wouldn't be possible to get the exact data that was passed to the embed/attach function.

mpkorstanje
2023-03-19 10:42:19

*Thread Reply:* It's not efficient to encode the data twice, but that's a different problem.

Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 10:42:24

*Thread Reply:* Yup, at this point information is lost, it would seem

Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 10:43:36

*Thread Reply:* Can I propose a PR?

mpkorstanje
2023-03-19 10:53:23

*Thread Reply:* Not my call. @David Goss does most of Cucumber JS.

Looking at the attachment_manager it looks pretty intentional when strings are used. I'm guessing this is an optimization in the JS ecosystem.

Maybe start with a bug report and reproducer. It'd be a waste of work to make a PR if the problem is misunderstood.

👍 Jonas Amundsen
Jonas Amundsen
2023-03-19 12:02:26

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2260

#2260 Missing content encoding for attachments in JSON reports
<p><strong>👓 What did you see?</strong></p> <p>Consider the following code adding two string attachments:</p> <pre><code>Given("a step", function () { const myString = "foobar" this.attach(myString, "text/plain"); this.attach(Buffer.from("foobar").toString("base64"), "base64:text/plain"); }); </code></pre> <p>This will create two envelopes (messages) with different <code>contentEncoding</code> (<code>IDENTITY</code> and <code>BASE64</code> respectively). However, this information (content encoding) is lost in the JSON report and the original data cannot be reproduced with certainty.</p> <p>Below is the JSON report:</p> <pre><code>[ { "description": "", "elements": [ { "description": "", "id": "a-feature;an-example", "keyword": "Example", "line": 2, "name": "an example", "steps": [ { "arguments": [], "keyword": "Given ", "line": 3, "name": "a step", "match": { "location": "features/definitions.js:3" }, "result": { "status": "passed", "duration": 492577 }, "embeddings": [ { "data": "foobar", "mime_type": "text/plain" }, { "data": "Zm9vYmFy", "mime_type": "text/plain" } ] } ], "tags": [], "type": "scenario" } ], "id": "a-feature", "line": 1, "keyword": "Feature", "name": "a feature", "tags": [], "uri": "features/foo.feature" } ] </code></pre> <p><strong>✅ What did you expect to see?</strong></p> <p>I guess for JSON reports to either only ever contain base64 encoded data <em>or</em> for content encoding to be propagated to the report.</p> <p><strong>📦 Which tool/library version are you using?</strong></p> <p>• cucumber-js: 9.0.1</p> <p><strong>🔬 How could we reproduce it?</strong></p> <p>Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <ol><li><code>git clone &lt;https://github.com/badeball/cucumber-reproducible-issues.git&gt;</code></li><li><code>cd cucumber-reproducible-issues/string-attachment-ambiguity</code></li><li><code>npm install</code></li><li><code>npx cucumber-js</code></li> </ol>
Labels
🐛 bug
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
David Goss
2023-03-20 01:21:46

*Thread Reply:* Hey Jonas!

I think this stems from the introduction of messages where attachments could be explicitly either text or base64. See also https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/1552. I’ll post something on the issue soon, we could do with checking what other implementations do - as Rien said it could be particular to JS since IIRC many tools that e.g. generate screenshots will give you them already base64-encoded.

Also, since I’m a little aware of your broader context, not sure if you’ve seen https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2239, would be good to get your thoughts.

#1552 attachments: support attaching already-encoded base64 content
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>
#2239 make json formatter reusable outside cucumber-js
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>

Michael Morris
2023-03-20 12:52:27

Ok, the optimization is PR'ed - https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/2263

#2263 Issue 2262 ES imports in parallel
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>Optimization in the support.ts file to gather the dynamic import Promises into an array and then resolve them with a single Promise.all() call.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p>This should yield a noticeable speedup on Cucumber installs with very large ES step definition libraries. Other Cucumber installs will be unaffected.</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• 🐎 Optimization - A change meant to make the code more performant.</p> <p><strong>♻️ Anything particular you want feedback on?</strong></p> <p>If there are other instances in the codebase where an await is inside a loop then this pattern should be applied there as well.</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☐ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☐ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ Users should know about my change ☑︎ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>

And here's the next one: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/2264

#2264 Issue 2105 more detailed error
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>The error message viewed when importing a CommonJS module or requiring an ES module is now customized.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p>Making life easier when simple mistakes are made. The error message Node gives when you try to import steps using CommonJS format or require an ES module are a bit cryptic. The new error message tells the user they are using the wrong directive and to either change the file's format or use the other directive to include the file.</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• ⚡ New feature (non-breaking change which adds new behaviour)</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☑︎ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☑︎ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ Users should know about my change ☑︎ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>

Michael Morris
2023-03-27 12:11:10

So, any thoughts on this? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/2269

#2269 api: Test Debug Flag / Pause between tests among other behaviors
<p><strong>🤔 What's the problem you're trying to solve?</strong></p> <p>While tests are being developed they sometimes need some debugging, especially when a browser driver is in play. At my last job I installed such a feature that was invoked using an npm config flag, but I think this feature is a good candidate to be moved into the direct core suite.</p> <p><strong>✨ What's your proposed solution?</strong></p> <p>Cucumber would have a --debug flag and would provide a means for userland code to react to it, possibly just a simply importable function that will return boolean whether the test is running in debug. The major reason for including this is configuring the various browser drivers out there (Selenium, Puppeteer, Playwright) is out of the scope of Cucumber, but tests using them are the most likely consumer of this feature. The userland script would run the tests with the browser GUI displayed (Headed mode) if the debug flag is set, and turn off any automatic expiry of the session so that the user is free to inspect what is going on in the browser.</p> <p>In addition to providing this flag Cucumber would pause between test runs and wait for the user to press a key. This can be done in userland with hooks and npm configuration options and looks like this:</p> <pre><code> async function waitforPrompt(prompt) { const rl = readline.createInterface({ input: process.stdin, output: process.stdout, }); return new Promise((resolve) =&gt; { rl.question(prompt, () =&gt; { rl.close(); resolve(); }); }); } if (process.env.npm_config_ucx_debug === "true") { After({ timeout: -1 }, async function (scenario) { await waitforPrompt(`Feature: ${scenario.gherkinDocument.feature.name}\nScenario: ${scenario.pickle.name}\nComplete. Press Enter to Continue.`); await this.tearDown(); }); } else { After(async function (scenario) { await this.tearDown(); }); } </code></pre> <p>This behavior isn't compatible with parallel running, so if the base debug flag and parallel are used the parallel flag is suppressed with a warning ("Cannot create parallel runners in debug mode")</p> <p><strong>⛏️ Have you considered any alternatives or workarounds?</strong></p> <p>This is doable in userland, but it's awkward and having a direct setup in the core library would be useful</p> <p><strong>📚 Any additional context?</strong></p> <p>I would like to have some discussion on this at length here or in slack before beginning. The addition of this flag has major implications and there are doubtless other areas of the suite I haven't thought of that might want to alter their behavior when it is present.</p>
Labels
⚡ enhancement
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js">cucumber/cucumber-js</a>

@Michael Morris This project gives out commit bit freely, and also has tools that revoke it over time, if you’re not active.

olleolleolle
2023-06-19 23:53:40

By allowing, rather than gate-keeping, we gain speed and trust in each other. (There are many eyes (and tools) on the ball, so weird things are not let through.)

olleolleolle
2023-06-19 23:54:17

This is my own interpretation of the Cucumber project’s ethos when it comes to allowing people in.

#249 CI: Use Node 18, 20
<p><strong>🤔 What's changed?</strong></p> <p>Fix <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/html-formatter/issues/219">#219</a> by changing the build matrix to use newer versions.</p> <p><strong>⚡ What's your motivation?</strong></p> <p>In order to keep up with Node versions that are current, and also, to conserve CI resources, use two Node.js versions. The two that are shown on the Node.js website.</p> <p>I will also update the other Workflow.</p> <p><strong>🏷️ What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>• 🏦 Refactoring/debt/DX (improvement to code design, tooling, documentation etc. without changing behaviour)</p> <p><strong>♻️ Anything particular you want feedback on?</strong></p> <p>n/a</p> <p><strong>📋 Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ☐ I've changed the behaviour of the code ☐ I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☐ Users should know about my change ☐ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../blob/main/CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>

#36 fix(deps): update dependency figures to v5
<p><a href="https://renovatebot.com">Mend Renovate</a></p> <p>This PR contains the following updates:</p> <hr /> <p><strong>Release Notes</strong> sindresorhus/figures <strong><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/releases/tag/v5.0.0"><code>v5.0.0</code></a></strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/compare/v4.0.1...v5.0.0">Compare Source</a></p> <p><strong>Breaking</strong></p> <p>• Require Node.js 14 (<a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/issues/91">#​91</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/commit/62b5c69"><code>62b5c69</code></a></p> <p><strong>Improvements</strong></p> <p>• Use a more suitable character for <code>cross</code> (<a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/issues/93">#​93</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/commit/ab27bdd"><code>ab27bdd</code></a></p> <p><strong><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/releases/tag/v4.0.1"><code>v4.0.1</code></a></strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/compare/v4.0.0...v4.0.1">Compare Source</a></p> <p>• Update dependencies <a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/commit/596a105"><code>596a105</code></a></p> <p><strong><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/releases/tag/v4.0.0"><code>v4.0.0</code></a></strong></p> <p><a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/compare/v3.2.0...v4.0.0">Compare Source</a></p> <p><strong>Breaking</strong></p> <p>• Require Node.js 12 (<a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/issues/79">#​79</a>) <a href="https://togithub.com/sindresorhus/figures/commit/5e8705e"><code>5e8705e</code></a> • This package is now pure ESM. David Goss
2024-04-27 00:54:47

Adding a new JS example for TypeScript+ESM, and doing a general refresh at the same time https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js-examples/pull/19 (I will start adding more examples here soon for popular use cases as I think it will help users a lot)

#19 Add TypeScript+ESM example, general refresh
<p>This PR:</p> <p>• Adds an example using TypeScript with ESM (including the newly-released <code>loader</code> option) distinct from the version using CommonJS • Gets all examples onto the latest version • Gets all examples using JSON config files • Fixes a few small issues • Bumps version of Node.js used in CI from 16 to 20</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js-examples">cucumber/cucumber-js-examples</a>
